pullRequest.title: Restructure to allow combining soft assertions entry points

node.title: Composable SoftAssertions entry-point classes
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Soft assertions are good.

I like being able to use soft assertions with my custom exceptions in my code.

One of the selling points of AssertJ is the single entry point, which makes it easy to simply type assertThat() in your IDE and have it automatically give you the list of applicable assertions.

I'd like to be able to easily combine soft assertions entry classes from multiple sources. This is not currently possible as Java doesn't support multiple inheritance for classes. The workaround is clunky - each project must maintain its own soft assertions entry point with all of the assertThats in it that they want.

Switching to a model based on interfaces and Java 8 default methods would make multiple inheritance possible.

Example

Current situation

public class Project1SoftAssertions extends SoftAssertions {
    public MyCustomAssert assertThat(MyCustom a) {
        return proxy(MyCustomAssert.class, MyCustom.class, a);
    }
}

public class Project2SoftAssertions extends SoftAssertions {
    public MyCustom2Assert assertThat(MyCustom2 a) {
        return proxy(MyCustom2Assert.class, MyCustom2.class, a);
    }
}

// Can't do this - multiple inheritance not permitted for classes
public class UberSoftAssertions extends Project1SoftAssertions, Project2SoftAssertions {
}

// Have to do this - lots of repetition if you've got lots of assertions!
public class UberSoftAssertions extends SoftAssertions {
    public MyCustomAssert assertThat(MyCustom a) {
        return proxy(MyCustomAssert.class, MyCustom.class, a);
    }
    public MyCustom2Assert assertThat(MyCustom2 a) {
        return proxy(MyCustom2Assert.class, MyCustom2.class, a);
    }
}

// Also can't do this:
public class JUnitJupiterUberSoftAssertions
    extends JUnitJupiterSoftAssertions,
        Project1SoftAssertions, Project2SoftAssertions {}

Proposed

There will be a single functional interface that all soft assertions classes must implement. This has one default method that is used to generate the proxy classes. Then subinterfaces of this interface can call this method in their default assertThat() implementations. Because the soft assertion entry points can be interfaces, you can combine several of them into a single class.

public interface SoftAssertionsBase {
    <V extends Assert<V, T>, T> V proxy(Class<V> assertClass, Class<T> actualClass, T actual);
}

// Existing implementation with the SoftAssertionsBase implementation added
public class AbstractSoftAssertions implements SoftAssertionsBase {
    // Note that there is also a TODO in the source for proxy() that adds the bound on V,
    // as per below.
    public <V extends Assert<V, T>, T> V proxy(Class<V> assertClass, Class<T> actualClass, T actual) {
        return proxies.createSoftAssertionProxy(assertClass, actualClass, actual);
    }
    ....
}

public interface StandardSoftAssertions extends SoftAssertionsBase {
    // All of the standard assertThat assertions go in here as default methods.
}

public interface Project1SoftAssertions extends SoftAssertionsBase {
    default MyCustomAssert assertThat(MyCustom a) {
        return proxy(MyCustomAssert.class, MyCustom.class, a);
    }
}

public class Project2SoftAssertions extends SoftAssertionsBase {
    public MyCustom2Assert assertThat(MyCustom2 a) {
        return proxy(MyCustom2Assert.class, MyCustom2.class, a);
    }
}

// Now we can do this
public class UberSoftAssertions extends AbstractStandardSoftAssertions
    implements Project1SoftAssertions, Project2SoftAssertions {
}

// And this
public class JUnitJupiterUberSoftAssertions
    extends JUnitJupiterSoftAssertions
    implements Project1SoftAssertions, Project2SoftAssertions {}

// And this, which allows us to get rid of that annoying "softly." prefix on all assertions:
public class MyTest extends SoftAssertions implements Project1SoftAssertions, Project2SoftAssertions {

    @AfterAll
    public void after() {
        assertAll();
    }
}

Please note that, although JDK < 1.8 is dying rapidly, nonetheless the above is still JDK <1.8 compatible because it's only the custom extension entry points that need to be interfaces with default methods. If you're pre JDK 1.8, simply define your custom extension entry points as classes (as you always have) and you're back where we started.

pullRequest.title: Adding hasSameBinaryContentAs

node.title: Comparing equal binary files fails with java.nio.charset.MalformedInputException
node.bodyHTML:
Comparing equal binary files fails with a "java.nio.charset.MalformedInputException: Input length = 1" exception. Method that fails: "FileAssert.hasSameContentAs(java.io.File)".

This is actually caused by a wrong 'fall back' in the 'org.assertj.core.internal.Files' class:

BinaryDiffResult binaryDiffResult = binaryDiff.diff(actual, readAllBytes(expected.toPath()));
if (binaryDiffResult.hasNoDiff()) {
    // fall back to the RuntimeIOException : not throwing an error is wrong as there was one in the first place.
   throw e;
}

In fact this only means the both files are binary qual and it should be:

BinaryDiffResult binaryDiffResult = binaryDiff.diff(actual, readAllBytes(expected.toPath()));
if (binaryDiffResult.hasNoDiff()) {
   // Both files are binary equal
   return;
}

I added a pull request with the fix and added a test.

node.title: Add hasSuperclass(Class<?>) to AbstractClassAssert
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Sometimes I feel the lack of isNotAssignableFrom() in AbstractClassAssert.
Recently I needed a defensive test to enforce an exception class staying "checked" (i.e., not inheriting from RuntimeException). To do that, I created a custom condition:

private static Condition<Class<?>> runtimeException = new Condition<>(RuntimeException.class::isAssignableFrom, RuntimeException.class.getSimpleName());

used in this way:

assertThat(MyException.class).isNot(runtimeException);

Example

Following the behavior of the existing isAssignableFrom(Class<?>...), a new api could check that actual is not assignable from any of the others:

public SELF isNotAssignableFrom(Class<?>... others)

With it, my example would not require a custom condition:

assertThat(RuntimeException.class).isNotAssignableFrom(MyException.class);

Would this new api make sense?

Additional Thoughts

Would it make sense to have some assertions for Throwable classes, for example to verify if the class is inheriting from Error/Exception/RuntimeException? It would address the ugly backwards readability of isAssignableFrom :-)
Maybe a new AbstractThrowableClassAssert inheriting from AbstractClassAssert could to the job.

When I try to upgrade assertj-core from 3.11.1 to the latest version 3.14.0. The following code breaks.

import static org.assertj.core.api.Assertions.assertThat;

import java.nio.file.Path;
import java.nio.file.Paths;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Map;

import org.junit.Test;

public class Testassertj {

        Map<Path, String> test = new HashMap<Path, String>();

node.title: Feature Request: compare inputstream without keeping everything in memory
node.bodyHTML:
Currently org.assertj.core.internal.InputStreams.assertEqualContent reads everything into StringBuffers before doing a diff, which is prone to OutOfMemoryError when the inputs are large. It'd be nice to have a way to skip diff'ing and just compare equality without running out of memory.

@andrewgaul also hit this problem before.

pullRequest.title: Add ignoreFieldsForTypes to RecursiveComparisonConfiguration

node.title: Recursive comparison that ignore fields by types
node.bodyHTML:
.usingRecursiveComparison() is really useful for objects that don't override equals and hashcode.

In order to assert an object with fields that has random values, like id, uuid or datetime, I'll need to ignore them using this method:
https://github.com/joel-costigliola/assertj-core/blob/master/src/main/java/org/assertj/core/api/RecursiveComparisonAssert.java#L251

RecursiveComparisonConfiguration ignoreIdConfig = new RecursiveComparisonConfiguration();
ignoreIdConfig.ignoreFields("idFieldName");
assertThat(actual)
        .usingRecursiveComparison(ignoreIdConfig)
        .isEqualTo(expected);

It works like a charm, but supplying the field name with a string is not type-safe, I wonder if it's possible to add a method that can take field type as arguments like this:

ignoreIdConfig.ignoreFields(ZonedDateTime.class, UUID.class);

So it will match and ignore any fields with the given types.

node.title: Assertion hasNoNullFieldsOrProperties() throw error for delegate Map implementation
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

We have some own classes with extra logic that implement Map interface but delegate invocation to backed HashMap. This is related commit 337f99e

Example

 @Test
    void expectedHasNoNullFieldsOrProperties() {
        DelegateMap map = new DelegateMap(new HashMap<>());
        Assertions.assertThat(map).hasNoNullFieldsOrProperties();
    }

    static class DelegateMap implements Map<String, String> {

        private final Map<String, String> delegate;

        public DelegateMap(Map<String, String> delegate) {
            this.delegate = delegate;
        }

        @Override
        public int size() {
            return delegate.size();
        }

        @Override
        public boolean isEmpty() {
            return delegate.isEmpty();
        }

        @Override
        public boolean containsKey(Object key) {
            return delegate.containsKey(key);
        }

        @Override
        public boolean containsValue(Object value) {
            return delegate.containsValue(value);
        }

        @Override
        public String get(Object key) {
            return delegate.get(key);
        }

        @Override
        public String put(String key, String value) {
            return delegate.put(key, value);
        }

        @Override
        public String remove(Object key) {
            return delegate.remove(key);
        }

        @Override
        public void putAll(Map<? extends String, ? extends String> m) {
            delegate.putAll(m);
        }

        @Override
        public void clear() {
            delegate.clear();
        }

        @Override
        public Set<String> keySet() {
            return delegate.keySet();
        }

        @Override
        public Collection<String> values() {
            return delegate.values();
        }

        @Override
        public Set<Entry<String, String>> entrySet() {
            return delegate.entrySet();
        }

        @Override
        public boolean equals(Object o) {
            return delegate.equals(o);
        }

        @Override
        public int hashCode() {
            return delegate.hashCode();
        }

        @Override
        public String getOrDefault(Object key, String defaultValue) {
            return delegate.getOrDefault(key, defaultValue);
        }

        @Override
        public void forEach(BiConsumer<? super String, ? super String> action) {
            delegate.forEach(action);
        }

        @Override
        public void replaceAll(BiFunction<? super String, ? super String, ? extends String> function) {
            delegate.replaceAll(function);
        }

        @Override
        public String putIfAbsent(String key, String value) {
            return delegate.putIfAbsent(key, value);
        }

        @Override
        public boolean remove(Object key, Object value) {
            return delegate.remove(key, value);
        }

        @Override
        public boolean replace(String key, String oldValue, String newValue) {
            return delegate.replace(key, oldValue, newValue);
        }

        @Override
        public String replace(String key, String value) {
            return delegate.replace(key, value);
        }

        @Override
        public String computeIfAbsent(String key, Function<? super String, ? extends String> mappingFunction) {
            return delegate.computeIfAbsent(key, mappingFunction);
        }

        @Override
        public String computeIfPresent(String key, BiFunction<? super String, ? super String, ? extends String> remappingFunction) {
            return delegate.computeIfPresent(key, remappingFunction);
        }

        @Override
        public String compute(String key, BiFunction<? super String, ? super String, ? extends String> remappingFunction) {
            return delegate.compute(key, remappingFunction);
        }

        @Override
        public String merge(String key, String value, BiFunction<? super String, ? super String, ? extends String> remappingFunction) {
            return delegate.merge(key, value, remappingFunction);
        }
    }

node.title: Custom Assertions and comparison failures
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Trying to write custom assertions. The examples given show the use of failWithMessage().

The problem with failWithMessage() is that it doesn't populate the "expected" and "actual" fields of the generated assertion. These fields are useful to have populated where it makes sense to do so (eg, equality assertions on individual fields) as the IDEs use them to support graphical diff.

I can ignore failWithMessage() and generate an org.opentest4j.AssertionFailedError and populate these fields manually; however when I do so it is hard to honour the error reporting customisation interface of AbstractAssert. Similarly, it is hard to inherit/honor things like comparison strategy.

Possible solutions

-Introduce a new method in AbstractAssert which provides functionality for generating a ComparisonFailure or related assertion.
-AssertJ currently divides its packages into two types:
--Internal
--Consumer
I believe that AssertJ would benefit from the addition of a "service provider interface" (SPI) category of packages - comprised of classes and utilities that are intended for use by assertion implementors but not assertion users. At present, there are many classes in the "internal" package which understandably we wouldn't want to expose to assertion users, but could be really useful to implementors of custom assertions.
-It is possible that all of this is possible in AssertJ already and I simply don't know how to do it. If that is the case, it would be nice if the custom assertion doc page gave some examples of how to do this.

pullRequest.title: Support custom soft assertions in SoftAssertionExtension

node.title: SoftAssertionExtension to support custom soft assertions
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

The current implementation of SoftAssertionExtension is hardcoded to support SoftAssertions and BDDSoftAssertions. If you have your own custom soft assertions entry point (with your own custom assertions), then you're out of luck.

Example

class MySoftAssertions extends SoftAssertions {
  public CustomAssert assertThat(Custom actual) {
    return proxy(CustomAssert.class, Custom.class, actual);
  }
}
@ExtendWith(SoftAssertionsExtension.class)
public class MyTest {
  @Test 
  void my_test_method(MySoftAssertions softly) {
    // Parameter "softly" will not resolve
  }
}

pullRequest.title: Feat new method is directory recursively containing

node.title: How is isDirectoryContaining supposed to work?
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

I don't understand how org.assertj.core.api.AbstractFileAssert.isDirectoryContaining(String) is supposed to work (or is its Javadoc wrong?): According to its Javadoc

Verify that the actual File is a directory containing at least one file matching the given String interpreted as a path matcher (as per FileSystem.getPathMatcher(String)).

Note that the actual File must exist and be a directory.

Given the following directory structure:

 /root/
 /root/sub-dir-1/
 /root/sub-dir-1/file-1.ext
 /root/sub-dir-1/file-2.ext
 /root/sub-file-1.ext
 /root/sub-file-2.ext
Here are some assertions examples:
 File root = new File("root");

 // The following assertions succeed:
 assertThat(root).isDirectoryContaining("glob:**sub-dir*")
                 .isDirectoryContaining("glob:**sub-file*")
                 .isDirectoryContaining("glob:**.ext")
                 .isDirectoryContaining("regex:.*ext")
                 .isDirectoryContaining("glob:**.{ext,bin");

 // The following assertions fail:
 assertThat(root).isDirectoryContaining("glob:**dir");
 assertThat(root).isDirectoryContaining("glob:**.bin");
 assertThat(root).isDirectoryContaining("glob:**.{java,class}");

If I have a directory "root/com/example/Example.java", then this assertion should succeed (where outputDirectory is "root"):

assertThat(outputDirectory)
			.isDirectoryContaining("glob:**.java");

But it fails saying that the directory contents is "com".

node.title: ByteArrayAssert#containsExactly(byte...) error message should state which elements were not found and not expected
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

AbstractByteArrayAssert#containsExactly(byte...) produces a sub-optimal error message where the expected and actual values are printed out as memory addresses of those arrays, while I would expect a summary of which elements were not found and which were not expected within the potentially long array.

Example

org.opentest4j.AssertionFailedError: 
Expecting:
 <[1, 2, 4]>
to be equal to:
 <[1, 2, 3]>
but was not.
Expected :[B@764faa6
Actual   :[B@4c1f22f3

In case of int arrays the error message is much more helpful:

java.lang.AssertionError: 
Expecting:
  <[1, 2, 4]>
to contain exactly (and in same order):
  <[1, 2, 3]>
but some elements were not found:
  <[3]>
and others were not expected:
  <[4]>

From the source code it's visible that the byte array specific containsExactly method calls objects.assertEqual(info, actual, values), but the int array specific containsExactly method calls arrays.assertContainsExactly(info, actual, arrays.toByteArray(values)).

It hints that the byte array specific containsExactly method should have also called arrays.assertContainsExactly(info, actual, values);

Reproduction steps:

AssertJ version 3.15.0

assertThat(new byte[] { 1, 2, 4 }).containsExactly((byte) 1, (byte) 2, (byte) 3);

pullRequest.title: Stream has binary content

node.title: Add hasBinaryContent for InputStream
node.bodyHTML:
I would like to assert that a given input string returns a given binary content.
Since InputStream contains bytes, I'd suggest to provide the method hasBinaryContent that is also available for File. I'm currently using hasSameContentAs as a workaround, but that's not optimal.

byte[] expected = TEST_CONTENT;

InputStream inputStream = storage.getDownloadStream(TEST_URI);

// currently not supported:
assertThat(inputStream).hasBinaryContent(expected);
// workaround:
assertThat(inputStream).hasSameContentAs(new ByteArrayInputStream(expected));

pullRequest.title: Allow assertions on the (root) cause message

node.title: Allow assertion on the root cause message
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

It is currently not directly possible to assert on the root cause message. There is a workaround possible by using hasStackTraceContaining, but it would be nice if this was supported directly.

See also https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38943346/assertj-assert-on-the-cause-message

Example

I would like to be able to do this:

assertThatExceptionOfType(PersistenceException.class)
    .isThrownBy(() -> {
        // test code here
    })
   .withRootCauseInstanceOf(PSQLException.class)
   .withRootCauseMessageMatching("Key (user_id)=(.*) is not present in table \"book\"");

So to be consistent, probably the following new methods are needed:

  • withRootCauseMessageStartingWith(String description)
  • withRootCauseMessageContaining(String description)
  • withRootCauseMessageContainingAll(CharSequence... values)
  • withRootCauseMessageNotContaining(String content)
  • withRootCauseMessageNotContainingAny(CharSequence... values)
  • withRootCauseMessageMatching(String regex)
  • withRootCauseMessageEndingWith(String description)

pullRequest.title: Fix ShouldContain/ShouldContainOnly use a more specific name in error message

node.title: ShouldContainXXX: allow to replace "elements" by a more specific name
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

ShouldContainOnly is used in a few places where we know what kind of elements we are dealing with, in this case instead of using the term element we could use a more descriptive name.

Example

Spliterator<?> actual = createSpliterator(SORTED | ORDERED);
spliterators.assertHasOnlyCharacteristics(INFO, actual, DISTINCT, SORTED);

fails with this error

Expecting:
  <["ORDERED", "SORTED"]>
to contain only:
  <["DISTINCT", "SORTED"]>
elements not found:
  <["DISTINCT"]>
and elements not expected:
  <["ORDERED"]>

but we could have

Expecting spliterator characteristics:
  <["ORDERED", "SORTED"]>
to contain only:
  <["DISTINCT", "SORTED"]>
characteristics not found:
  <["DISTINCT"]>
and characteristics not expected:
  <["ORDERED"]>

Same thing for ShouldContain.

node.title: isXmlEqualToContentOf and similar checks should enable description on parse exception
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

When running xml comparisons, it would be useful to be able to print the xml on parse exceptions using as().

Currently a RuntimeException is thrown instead of an assertion error.

Example

assertThat("<foo></bar>").as("show me").isXmlEqualTo("<foo></foo>");

causes "show me" not to be printed

[Fatal Error] :1:8: The element type "foo" must be terminated by the matching end-tag "</foo>".

java.lang.RuntimeException: Unable to format XML string

	at org.assertj.core.util.xml.XmlStringPrettyFormatter.toXmlDocument(XmlStringPrettyFormatter.java:73)
	at org.assertj.core.util.xml.XmlStringPrettyFormatter.xmlPrettyFormat(XmlStringPrettyFormatter.java:45)
	at org.assertj.core.internal.Strings.assertXmlEqualsTo(Strings.java:877)
	at org.assertj.core.api.AbstractCharSequenceAssert.isXmlEqualTo(AbstractCharSequenceAssert.java:980)
	at com.example.Example.testExample(Example.java:19)
Caused by: org.xml.sax.SAXParseException; lineNumber: 1; columnNumber: 8; The element type "foo" must be terminated by the matching end-tag "</foo>".
	at org.apache.xerces.parsers.DOMParser.parse(Unknown Source)
	at org.apache.xerces.jaxp.DocumentBuilderImpl.parse(Unknown Source)
	at org.assertj.core.util.xml.XmlStringPrettyFormatter.toXmlDocument(XmlStringPrettyFormatter.java:71)
	... 32 more```

pullRequest.title: Added asHexString() in AbstractByteArrayAssert

node.title: ByteArrayAssert with Hex-Strings
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Hi i am using a lot of hexadecimal strings in my byte[] Tests. I think the code and the dependency tree could be nicer.
What do you think about this method?

I will write a pull request if this improvement is welcome.

Example

Usage of the new method:

 assertThat(new byte[] { (byte) 255 , 2  }).asHexString().isEqualTo("FF02");

 assertThat(new byte[] { (byte) 255 , 2  }).asHexString().isEqualTo("AF02");
org.opentest4j.AssertionFailedError: 
Expecting:
 <"FF02">
to be equal to:
 <"AF02">
but was not.

Implementation suggestion:

public abstract class AbstractByteArrayAssert<SELF extends AbstractByteArrayAssert<SELF>>
    extends AbstractArrayAssert<SELF, byte[], Byte> {
....
  public AbstractStringAssert<?> asHexString() {
    objects.assertNotNull(info, actual);
    return Assertions.assertThat(Hexadecimals.toHexString(actual));
  }

node.title: Files#temporaryFolder() will fail if System temporary folder does not exist
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

We noticed this issue when working on a docker based build. We found that the Java defined property for java.io.tmpdir was defined but the folder did not exist. This caused calls to Files#temporaryFolder to fail with the exception:

org.assertj.core.api.exception.RuntimeIOException: Unable to find temporary directory

Example

    public static void main(String ... args) {
        System.setProperty("java.io.tmpdir", "badger");
        assertThat(new File(System.getProperty("java.io.tmpdir"))).doesNotExist();
        Files.temporaryFolder(); // Will fail
    }

The following code sample would resolve this issue. I am happy to raise this as a pull request if this issue is considered valid.

    public static File temporaryFolder() {
        File temp = new File(Files.temporaryFolderPath());
        if (!temp.isDirectory()) {
            throw new RuntimeIOException("Unable to find temporary directory");
        }
        if (!temp.exists() && !temp.mkdirs()) {
            throw new RuntimeIOException("Failed to create temporary directory");
        }
        return temp;
    }

pullRequest.title: #1505 Be more descriptive in assertThat(Throwable) by including the stacktrace

node.title: Be more descriptive in assertThat(Throwable) by including the stacktrace
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

I was happy to find an assertThat specifically for Throwable, but it ignores the stacktrace contained within. It should describe the value using the stacktrace instead of simply .toString().

Example

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Exception e;
        try {
            throw new RuntimeException();
        } catch (RuntimeException e2) {
            e = e2;
        }

        assertThat(e).isNull();
    }

Output:

Exception in thread "main" org.junit.ComparisonFailure: expected: but was:<java.lang.RuntimeException>
at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0(Native Method)
at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:62)
at sun.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:45)
at Test.main(Test.java:35)

Workaround

To work around it I have to manually describe it using a custom utility (in this case I used Apache Commons Lang):

assertThat(e).as(ExceptionUtils.getStackTrace(e)).isNull();

Output:

Exception in thread "main" org.junit.ComparisonFailure: [Exception:
java.lang.RuntimeException
at Test.main(Test.java:30)
] expected: but was:<java.lang.RuntimeException>
at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0(Native Method)
at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:62)
at sun.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:45)
at Test.main(Test.java:35)

pullRequest.title: Add assertion HasOnlyFields

node.title: Provide a way to assert all the fields a given class can contain
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

It would be nice if AssertJ provides a way to check that a given class contains only a certain set of fields/members. I (and probably others) usually test creation/instantiation workflows for POJOs; for instance:

import nl.jqno.equalsverifier.EqualsVerifier
import org.assertj.core.api.Assertions
import org.junit.jupiter.api.Test
import java.time.Clock
import java.time.ZonedDateTime

internal class IssueTest {
  @Test
  fun `create proper instance`() {
    val start = ZonedDateTime.now(Clock.systemUTC())
    val instance = Issue("the title", "some description", "full content")
    val end = ZonedDateTime.now(Clock.systemUTC())
    Assertions.assertThat(instance)
        .hasNoNullFieldsOrPropertiesExcept("id")
        .satisfies {
          Assertions.assertThat(it.title).isEqualTo("the title")
          Assertions.assertThat(it.description).isEqualTo("some description")
          Assertions.assertThat(it.content).isEqualTo("full content")
          Assertions.assertThat(it.status).isEqualTo(Issue.Status.CREATED)
          Assertions.assertThat(it.createdAt).isBetween(start, end)
          Assertions.assertThat(it.modifiedAt).isBetween(start, end)
          Assertions.assertThat(it.version).isEqualTo(0)
        }
  }

  @Test
  fun `contract between equals and hashCode must be fulfilled`() {
    EqualsVerifier.forClass(Issue::class.java)
        .withIgnoredFields("createdAt", "modifiedAt", "id", "version")
        .verify()
  }
}

In that realm, we keep adding/removing/updating/modifying members, so having that kind of assertion(s) will let you have more confidence when you do such things.

I see there is already a hasFieldOrProperty("fieldName"), so I'm thinking about something like hasOnlyFieldsOrProperties("field1", "field2", ..., "fieldN").

In the end, I'm not sure if this is super useful for some others, but I thought I would start somewhere

pullRequest.title: Add usingConfigurableRecursiveFieldByFieldElementComparator.

node.title: usingRecursiveFieldByFieldElementComparator and usingComparatorForType unexpected behavior
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

I faced an unexpected behavior (for me) with usingRecursiveFieldByFieldElementComparator and usingComparatorForType .

I'd except them to go recursively through all fields and check each field value. But something seems to be checking for the hash/equals before doing so.

In the example bellow the test that works() uses @lombok.Getter which does not override hash/equals, the test that fails() uses @lombok.Value which does override.

If that's not a bug, It would be good to have something to add clarity to this issue.

Example

package com.example.hi;

import com.example.hi.ExampleTest.Foo.Bar;
import com.example.hi.ExampleTest.One.Two;
import lombok.AllArgsConstructor;
import lombok.Getter;
import lombok.Value;
import org.junit.jupiter.api.Test;

import java.time.LocalDateTime;
import java.time.temporal.ChronoUnit;
import java.util.Comparator;
import java.util.List;
import java.util.Map;

import static java.util.Collections.singletonList;
import static org.assertj.core.api.Assertions.assertThat;

public class ExampleTest {

    Comparator<LocalDateTime> truncateSeconds = (a, exp) ->
        a.isAfter(exp.truncatedTo(ChronoUnit.SECONDS)) ? 0 : 1;

    @Test
    void works() {

        var a = new Foo(Map.of("one", singletonList(new Bar(LocalDateTime.now()))));
        var b = new Foo(Map.of("one", singletonList(new Bar(LocalDateTime.now()))));

        assertThat(singletonList(a))
            .usingRecursiveFieldByFieldElementComparator()
            .usingComparatorForType(truncateSeconds, LocalDateTime.class)
            .containsExactly(b);
    }

    @Test
    void fails() {

        var a = new One(Map.of("one", singletonList(new Two(LocalDateTime.now()))));
        var b = new One(Map.of("one", singletonList(new Two(LocalDateTime.now()))));

        assertThat(singletonList(a))
            .usingRecursiveFieldByFieldElementComparator()
            .usingComparatorForType(truncateSeconds, LocalDateTime.class)
            .containsExactly(b);
    }

    @Getter
    @AllArgsConstructor
    public static class Foo {

        Map<String, List<Bar>> values;

        @Getter
        @AllArgsConstructor
        public static class Bar {

            LocalDateTime date;
        }
    }

    @Value
    @AllArgsConstructor
    public static class One {

        Map<String, List<Two>> values;

        @Value
        @AllArgsConstructor
        public static class Two {

            LocalDateTime date;
        }
    }
}

node.title: Allow element comparator to use the new recursive comparison
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

The current usingRecursiveFieldByFieldElementComparatoris fairly rigid as it is not based on the new recursive comparison.

Opening it to the new recursive comparison would make much more flexible allowing users to call iterable assertions (when the new recursive API only exposes isEqualTo assertion).

This approach does not expose a nice fluent API like RecursiveComparisonAssert, users will have to build the RecursiveComparisonConfiguration to use, this can be made more user friendly by adding a builder to RecursiveComparisonConfiguration.

Should we change to usingRecursiveFieldByFieldElementComparator to be usingConfigurableRecursiveFieldByFieldElementComparator(newRecursiveComparisonConfiguration()) ?

That would be a breaking change and make methods like usingComparatorForElementFieldsWithNames, usingComparatorForElementFieldsWithType, usingElementComparatorOnFields irrelevant.

The API for recursive comparison should be cleaned as it exposes (too) many way to perform recursive comparison.

Example

Foo actual = new Foo("1", new Bar(1));
Foo other = new Foo("2", new Bar(1));

RecursiveComparisonConfiguration configuration = new RecursiveComparisonConfiguration();
configuration.ignoreFields("id");

// succeeds as we ignore id which differs in 
assertThat(list(actual)).usingConfigurableRecursiveFieldByFieldElementComparator(configuration)
                        .contains(other);

where Foo and Bar are defined like:

public static class Foo {
  String id;
  Bar bar;
  public Foo(String id, Bar bar) {
    this.id = id;
    this.bar = bar;
  }
}

public static class Bar {
  public int id;
  public Bar(int id) {
    this.id = id;
  }
}

pullRequest.title: Fix issue #1879: allow failures to be recorded from multiple threads

mergeCommit.message: Fix issue #1879: allow failures to be recorded from multiple threads (#1880)

nodes.message: Replace orElseGet by orElseThrow to throw an error

node.title: There appears no way to add failures to SoftAssertions from multiple threads
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Consider I need to collect multiple failures produced in multiple threads. Currently, SoftAssertions doesn't allow me to do so w/o extra synchronizers.

Example

For example, this code is broken because changes made to the SoftAssertions instance from other threads might not be visible from the main thread:

        final SoftAssertions softly = new SoftAssertions();

        final ForkJoinPool forkJoinPool = ForkJoinPool.commonPool();
        forkJoinPool.execute(() -> {
            softly.assertThat("foo").hasToString("foo");
        });
        forkJoinPool.execute(() -> {
            softly.assertThat("bar").hasToString("bar");
        });

        softly.assertAll();

What is the best approach to solve the above problem?

Guarding SoftAssertions with a synchronized block wherever I'm accessing the instance doesn't seem like a good solution (especially from test readability standpoint).

Probably you could introduce something like SynchronizedSoftAssertions or least make the list of failures a synchronized list. At the same time, it's not clear how to guard the whole call chain like

softly.assertThat("foo").hasToString("foo");

with a single lock.

pullRequest.title: Add satisfy in AbstractIterableAssert

node.title: Consumer-based "satisfy" assertions for elements in arrays and iterables
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Consider extending the assertions API for arrays and iterables with satisfy* methods accepting multiple Consumer<? super ELEMENT>s. The consumers probe the individual elements of the tested collection.

The additional methods could be:

  • satisfy(Consumer<? super ELEMENT>... consumers): For each element of the tested collection the (remaining) consumers are called; if a consumer accepts the element, then the element and that consumer are removed from their collections and the next element is probed.
  • satisfyExactly(Consumer<? super ELEMENT>... consumers): The tested collection must have the same size as the consumers. Each element of the tested collection is fed to the corresponding consumer.
  • satisfyExactlyInAnyOrder(Consumer<? super ELEMENT>... consumers): The tested collection must have the same size as the consumers. For each element of the tested collection the (remaining) consumers are called; if a consumer accepts the element, then the element and that consumer are removed from their collections and the next element is probed.

This would allow more flexible assertions on arrays and iterables.

Example

assertThat(trilogy).satisfy(movie -> {
    // the two Towers
    assertThat(movie.getReleaseDate()).isEqualTo(parse("2002-12-18"));
    assertThat(movie.getTitle()).contains("Towers");
  }, 
  movie -> {
    // the fellowship of the Ring
    assertThat(movie.getReleaseDate()).isBefore(parse("2002-12-17"));
    assertThat(movie.xrated).isFalse();
  }
);

assertThat(trilogy).satisfyExactly(movie -> {
    // the fellowship of the Ring
    assertThat(movie.getReleaseDate()).isBefore(parse("2002-12-17"));
    assertThat(movie.xrated).isFalse();
  }, 
  movie -> {
    // the two Towers
     assertThat(movie.getReleaseDate()).isEqualTo(parse("2002-12-18"));
     assertThat(movie.getTitle()).contains("Towers");
  }, 
  movie -> {
    // the Return of the King
    assertThat(movie.getTitle()).endsWith("King");
  }
);

assertThat(trilogy).satisfyExactlyInAnyOrder(movie -> {
    // the two Towers
    assertThat(movie.getReleaseDate()).isEqualTo(parse("2002-12-18"));
    assertThat(movie.getTitle()).contains("Towers");
  }, 
  movie -> {
    // the fellowship of the Ring
    assertThat(movie.getReleaseDate()).isBefore(parse("2002-12-17"));
    assertThat(movie.xrated).isFalse();
  }, 
  movie -> {
    // the Return of the King
    assertThat(movie.getTitle()).endsWith("King");
  }
);

Alternatives

The current API provides the following alternatives (for the proposed satisfyExactlyInAnyOrder method):

  1. extracting multiple fields and assert matching tuples:
assertThat(trilogy)
  .extracting(Movie::getTitle, Movie::getReleaseDate, movie -> movie.xrated)
  .containsExactlyInAnyOrder(
    tuple("the Return of the King", parse("2003-12-17"), false),
    tuple("the fellowship of the Ring", parse("2001-12-19"), false), 
    tuple("the two Towers", parse("2002-12-18"), false)
  );

This approach requires all values to match exactly, requires all elements to be tested for the same fields, is not type safe, and gets unreadable above three fields.

  1. Individual assertThat for each desired element with filterOn distinguishing characteristic of that element:
assertThat(trilogy).hasSize(3);

assertThat(trilogy)
  .filterOn(movie -> parse("2002-12-17").compareTo(movie.getReleaseDate()) > 0)
  .hasSize(1)
  .element(0)
  .satisfies(movie -> {
    assertThat(movie.xrated).isFalse();
  });

assertThat(trilogy)
  .filterOn("releaseDate", parse("2002-12-18"))
  .hasSize(1)
  .element(0)
  .satisfies(movie -> {
    assertThat(movie.getTitle()).contains("Towers");
  });

assertThat(trilogy)
  .filterOn(movie -> movie.getTitle().endsWith("King"))
  .hasSize(1);

While this approach is more flexible than the first, it is more verbose and does usually not reflect the mental model of how a list is tested.

pullRequest.title: Implement lazy withFailMessage / overridingErrorMessage

node.title: lazy withFailMessage /  overridingErrorMessage
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

junit provide a lazy fail message description by using a supplier. The supplier is called only if an error occurs, otherwise it is not called.

        Assertions.assertTrue(true, () -> "I won't be called");
        Assertions.assertTrue(false, () -> "I will be called");

It is useful for at least two reason :

  • performance optimization if computing the custom error message is costly.
  • getting error message may not be possible if there is not an error, however assertThat try to get the error message even if there is no error.

Suggestion, add the same capability to withFailMEssage or overridingErrorMessage, example :

        assertThat(response.isError())
            .withFailMessage(() -> "my error")
            .isFalse();

pullRequest.title: Provide comparable assertions for non comparable class when given a comparator

node.title: Provide comparable assertions for non comparable class when given a comparator
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Comparable assertions are restricted to Comparable types, this could extended for non Comparable types if a proper Comparator is given.

This is issue was created after this discussion https://stackoverflow.com/questions/55811121/assertj-fluent-ordering-tests-with-custom-comparator/55828748?noredirect=1#comment98322628_55828748.

Example

Foo foo1 = ...;
Foo foo2 = ...;
FooComparator fooComparator = ...;
assertThat(foo1).usingComparator(fooComparator).isGreaterThan(foo2);

We want to avoid to copy comparable assertions in AbstractAssert as it would pollute the API.

The idea of this improvement is to return a ComparableAssert from usingComparator and then chain comparable assertions. Moreover we would ideally keep the original type assertions.
Whether this is technically possible is something to explore as part of this improvement.

node.title: filteredOn with Function for arrays and iterables
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Extend the fluent filter API for arrays and iterables with a method to filter based on a Function<? super ELEMENT, T> parameter (e.g., a method reference to a getter) and a T parameter (for matching).

The approach is similar to the extracting(Function<? super ELEMENT, V>) method. It will allow a save filtering without introspection.

Example

assertThat(fellowshipOfTheRing).filteredOn(TolkienCharacter::getRace, HOBBIT)
                                   .containsOnly(sam, frodo, pippin, merry);

assertThat(fellowshipOfTheRing).filteredOn(character -> character.getRace().getName(), "Hobbit")
                                   .containsOnly(sam, frodo, pippin, merry);

pullRequest.title: Add assertThatNoException() method

node.title: Consider adding an assertThatNoException method
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

The assertThatExceptionOfType method and related helpers (assertThatNullPointerException, assertThatIllegalArgumentException, assertThatIOException & assertThatIllegalStateException) provide a nice way to check that a specific exception has been thrown.

If, however, you want to check that an exception was not thrown you need to use assertThatCode and follow it with doesNotThrowAnyException. It would be really nice to have an assertThatNoException method, so that exception tests can consistently lead with the assertion.

Example

Current:

assertThatIllegalArgumentException().isThrownBy(() -> new Foo(null, "bar"));
assertCode(() -> new Foo("foo", null)).doesNotThrowAnyException();

Wanted:

assertThatIllegalArgumentException().isThrownBy(() -> new Foo(null, "bar"));
assertThatNoException().isThrownBy(() -> new Foo("foo", null));

pullRequest.title: Fix 1898

node.title: Performance regression in 3.16.0: assertThat(byte[]).containsExactly(byte[])
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

While upgrading our codebase from AssertJ 3.15.0 to 3.16.1, one of our tests hung until a 40 minute timeout expired. It turned out that this test was calling assertThat(byte[]).containsExactly(byte[]) on some byte arrays with 20 million elements.

It appears that this assertion had linear performance characteristics in 3.15.0, but quadratic performance in 3.16.0, specifically changing at commit 3dc4004. For example, it now takes about two minutes to run this assertion on an array of size one million, vs. less than a second previously.

My current workaround is to just assert the truth of Arrays.equals().

Example

  @Test
  public void testScaleRegression() {
    // Times taken at assertj-core-3.16.1:
    // 8k: 15 ms
    // 16k: 39 ms
    // 32k: 101 ms
    // 64k: 371 ms
    // 128k: 1616 ms
    // 256k: 7398 ms
    // 512k: 31654 ms
    // 1024k: 118472 ms

    // Times taken at assertj-core-3.15.0:
    // 8k: 4 ms
    // 16k: 8 ms
    // 32k: 14 ms
    // 64k: 25 ms
    // 128k: 44 ms
    // 256k: 92 ms
    // 512k: 166 ms
    // 1024k: 339 ms
    for (int length : Arrays.asList(8_000, 8_000, 8_000, 16_000, 32_000, 64_000, 128_000, 256_000, 512_000, 1_024_000)) {
      byte[] data = new byte[length];
      Arrays.fill(data, (byte) 0x42);
      byte[] data2 = new byte[length];
      Arrays.fill(data2, (byte) 0x42);
      System.out.println("Testing for length " + length + "...");
      long startTime2 = System.currentTimeMillis();
      assertThat(data).containsExactly(data2);
      System.out.println("Done testing " + length + ", took " + (System.currentTimeMillis() - startTime2) + " ms");
    }
  }

pullRequest.title: FEATURE #1652 : assert return value of callable throwing exception

node.title: Assert return value of callable throwing exception
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

It would be nice if the assertThatCode().doesNotThrowException() API would be able execute functions that return a value and then return that value for further inspection.
This would make it easy to provide a nice description to an otherwise maybe nondescript exception that is thrown.

Example

@Test 
public void intendedApi() {
  int x = assertThatCode(this::doStuff)
    .describedAs("doing things")
    .doesNotThrowAnyException();
  assertThat(x).isEqualTo(3);
}

@Test
public void currentSolution1() {
  int x;
  try {
    x = doStuff();
  } catch (Exception e) {
    fail("doing things");
    return; // never reached; needed because fail() is not recognized by the java compiler as method exit
  }
  assertThat(x).isEqualTo(3);
}

@Test
public void currentSolution2() {
  AtomicReference<Integer> x = new AtomicReference<>();
  assertThatCode(() -> x.set(doStuff()))
    .describedAs("doing things")
    .doesNotThrowAnyException();
  assertThat(x.get()).isEqualTo(3);
}

// utility for demonstration purposes
public int doStuff() throws Exception {
  if (new Random().nextBoolean()) {
    throw new Exception();
  }
  return 3;
}

pullRequest.title: Add assertion factory methods to AbstractAssert.

node.title: AbstractAssert to add assertion factory methods
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Some of the utility methods in AbstractAssert that are commonly used by custom assertion implementations will always throw an exception. Specifically:

https://github.com/joel-costigliola/assertj-core/blob/3c6bb8a5d4f452c60cf3c8e336a03feba5e9b207/src/main/java/org/assertj/core/api/AbstractAssert.java#L143

https://github.com/joel-costigliola/assertj-core/blob/3c6bb8a5d4f452c60cf3c8e336a03feba5e9b207/src/main/java/org/assertj/core/api/AbstractAssert.java#L185

Unfortunately, methods like this are a pain for the compiler and for code coverage tools because they have no way of knowing that calls to these methods will never return normally. Hence you get code coverage maps that look like this:

https://codecov.io/gh/osgi/osgi-test/src/main/org.osgi.test.assertj.framework/src/main/java/org/osgi/test/assertj/bundlecontext/AbstractBundleContextAssert.java

...with the invocations of the failXXX() methods all showing up as uncovered. This happens because the way Codecov works is to insert probes (little bits of test code) before and after each line of source code - because the probe after the call to failXXX() never gets called, the code coverage tool concludes (incorrectly) that the line before it wasn't executed.

In order to fix this, it would be better if instead of throwing the exception directly, the two methods had counterparts which returned an exception that the caller could throw directly. So instead of:

if (!actual.getName().equals(name)) {
     failWithMessage("Expected character's name to be <%s> but was <%s>" name, actual.getName());
}

...you'd do something like this:

if (!actual.getName().equals(name)) {
     throw failureWithMessage("Expected character's name to be <%s> but was <%s>" name, actual.getName());
}

This way, the compiler and code coverage tools would be in on the secret and can handle appropriately, and our code coverage checks for our custom assertions would be showing 100% coverage instead of 87%.

This is more than just a "code coverage" nicety - the compiler can also work better (eg, spot dead code) with this pattern rather than the pattern of calling a method that always throws.

pullRequest.title: Better handle soft proxies for custom assert classes in OSGi bundles

mergeCommit.message:
Better handle soft proxies for custom assert classes in OSGi bundles (#1968)

We use a composite class loader for defining soft proxies when the
assert class is from a different class loader than the AssertJ classes.

This can occur in OSGi when the assert class is from a bundle. The
composite class loader provides access to the internal, non-exported
types of AssertJ. ByteBuddy will define the proxy class in the
CompositeClassLoader rather than in the class loader of the assert
class. This means the assert class cannot assume package private access
to super types, interfaces, etc. since the proxy class is defined in a
different class loader (the CompositeClassLoader) than the assert class.

Fixes https://github.com/joel-costigliola/assertj-core/issues/1964

Signed-off-by: BJ Hargrave <bj@bjhargrave.com>

nodes.message: Add missing ObjectArrayAssert_anySatisfy_Test

node.title: OSGi: soft proxy creation lacks visibilty to internal types
node.bodyHTML:
In the osgi-test project, we are developing custom AssertJ assertions and providing soft assertion support for them. Integration testing for the latest such custom assertion, show a class loading issue preventing creating the soft assertion proxy. The issue seems to be at

https://github.com/joel-costigliola/assertj-core/blob/0cadf3e19ff126fc96f2055d9923b6fb327a02be/src/main/java/org/assertj/core/api/SoftProxies.java#L198-L200

where it uses the class loader of the assertClass but the OSGi bundle holding the assertClass does not have visibility to the internal packages of AssertJ which also need to be visible to the ByteBuddy generated class. So when the integration test runs, we get the following error:

https://github.com/osgi/osgi-test/pull/176/checks?check_run_id=972751583#step:4:727

[INFO] --- bnd-testing-maven-plugin:5.1.2:testing (testing) @ org.osgi.test.junit5 ---
[INFO] Matching glob *
[INFO] Bnd inferred -runee: JavaSE-1.8
TEST org.osgi.test.junit5.dictionary.DictionaryAssertTest#testDictionarySoftAssertion() <<< ERROR: org/assertj/core/internal/TypeComparators
java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/assertj/core/internal/TypeComparators
	at java.lang.Class.getDeclaredMethods0(Native Method)
	at java.lang.Class.privateGetDeclaredMethods(Class.java:2701)
	at java.lang.Class.getDeclaredMethod(Class.java:2128)
	at org.osgi.test.assertj.dictionary.ProxyableDictionaryAssert$ByteBuddy$QRu2iZHZ.<clinit>(Unknown Source)
	at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:62)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:45)
	at java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance(Constructor.java:423)
	at org.assertj.core.api.SoftProxies.createSoftAssertionProxy(SoftProxies.java:118)
	at org.assertj.core.api.AbstractSoftAssertions.proxy(AbstractSoftAssertions.java:43)
	at org.osgi.test.assertj.dictionary.DictionarySoftAssertionsProvider.assertThat(DictionarySoftAssertionsProvider.java:32)
	at org.osgi.test.junit5.dictionary.DictionaryAssertTest.testDictionarySoftAssertion(DictionaryAssertTest.java:22)

The ByteBuddy generated class needs to use a class loader which can load classes from the class loader of the assertion class (assertClass.getClassLoader()) and also from the class loader of AssertJ so that internal types can be found. So I think the supplied class loader here needs to be a composite class loader over both assertClass.getClassLoader() and getClass().getClassLoader().

pullRequest.title: Implement singleElement for iterables

node.title: singleElement for iterables
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Add a method hasSingleElementThat to the assertions API for iterables that checks whether the iterable hasSize(1) and then returns element(0) for further assertions on that element.

I have stumbled across this pattern several times, so I wonder whether such a convenience method would make sense in the API.

Example

assertThat(newArrayList("Yoda")).hasSingleElementThat().startsWith("Yo");

pullRequest.title: Get the current actual

node.title: Provide a way to the get the current actual
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Some assertions have side effects or traverse the objects under test.

Sometimes, it is desirable to assert something, then perform additional manipulations on the object under test, before asserting more things.

In these cases, you have 2 choices:

  1. Perform the traversal outside of assertj and then assert as you reach the relevant pieces.
  2. Duplicate the traversal both with and without assertj

It would be useful instead if all assertions allowed for the actual object to be retrieved, removing this duplication.

Please let me know if there is already a way to do this (or a better approach) but I can't see one.

Below examples show this with succeedsWithin but the problem is not specific to succeedsWithin.

Inconvenient Alternative 1

  //no way to access what the future returned
  assertThat(future).succeedsWithin(10, TimeUnit.SECONDS);

  //Duplicate the traversal logic
  Object foo = future.get();

  //manipulate object outside of assertj
  //perform further assertions

Inconvenient Alternative 2

  //Get the underlying object first. Don't use assertj and lose the assertion failures if something goes wrong
  Object foo = future.get()  
  
  //manipulate object outside of assertj
  //perform further assertions

Desired Outcome

  Object foo = assertThat(future)
    .succeedsWithin(10, TimeUnit.SECONDS)
    .getActual();

  //manipulate object outside of assertj
  //perform further assertions

Proposed Solution

Just add a getter to AbstractAssert:

  public ACTUAL getActual() {
    return actual;
  }

pullRequest.title: Improve describe error readability of ElementsShouldSatisfy

mergeCommit.message:
Improve describe error readability of ElementsShouldSatisfy (#2012)

Previously, the error was appended after the toString of the element that did not satisfy the requirements. This was problematic for objects with a lengthy toString because it made the describe error difficult to identify. Now, the describe error is on a new line allowing for quick identification.

nodes.message:
Add failsWithin CompletableFuture assertion.
Fixes #1150

node.title: Improve describe error readability of ElementsShouldSatisfy
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

The error: <description> from ElementsShouldSatisfy should be on a new line to improve readability of objects with long toString().

Example

Consider a complex Object with many fields in its toString:

public class ObjectWithManyFields {

    private String field1;
    private String field2;
    // ... plus many more fields

    // getter, setters

    @Override
    public String toString() {
        return "ObjectWithManyFields{" +
                "field1='" + field1 + '\'' +
                ", field2='" + field2 + '\'' +
                // ... plus many more fields
                '}';
    }

}

Using allSatisfy

@Test
void someTest() {
    List<ObjectWithManyFields> objectsWithManyFields = new ArrayList<>();

    ObjectWithManyFields objectWithManyFields = new ObjectWithManyFields();
    objectWithManyFields.setField1("my field1");
    objectsWithManyFields.add(objectWithManyFields);

    assertThat(objectsWithManyFields).allSatisfy(o -> {
        assertThat(o.getField1()).as("Field 1").isEqualTo("some value");
        assertThat(o.getField2()).as("Field 2").isEqualTo("some other value");
        // etc.
    });
}

Yields this

java.lang.AssertionError: 
Expecting all elements of:
  <[ObjectWithManyFields{field1='my field1', field2='null', field3='null', field4='null', field5='null', field6='null', field7='null', field8='null', field9='null', field10='null', field11='null', field12='null', field13='null', field14='null', field15='null', field16='null', field17='null', field18='null', field19='null', field20='null', field21='null', field22='null', field23='null', field24='null', field25='null'}]>
to satisfy given requirements, but these elements did not:

  <ObjectWithManyFields{field1='my field1', field2='null', field3='null', field4='null', field5='null', field6='null', field7='null', field8='null', field9='null', field10='null', field11='null', field12='null', field13='null', field14='null', field15='null', field16='null', field17='null', field18='null', field19='null', field20='null', field21='null', field22='null', field23='null', field24='null', field25='null'}> error: [Field 1] 
Expecting:
 <"my field1">
to be equal to:
 <"some value">
but was not.

Now when I first came across this, right away I was unable to determine which assertion of my Consumer failed from my as() descriptions. I thought it was completely omitted. It was only when I scrolled right that I found the error.

It would be much better if the error description was on a new line after the toString representation of the object that failed the assertAllSatisfy.

Like this:

java.lang.AssertionError: 
Expecting all elements of:

pullRequest.title: Handle soft proxies for custom assert classes in OSGi bundles (#1979)

node.title: OSGi integration testing
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

AssertJ support in OSGi is pretty good. However, due to the funky classloading tricks that it uses (particularly with assumptions and soft assertions) you can sometimes run into issues. Searching the issues for "OSGi" will reveal a number of them (some of them still open). In the osgi-test project, we have recently hit a similar issue (osgi/osgi-test#118).

This suggestion has been made before (#1290 (comment)) that we include integration tests in AssertJ that exercise the OSGi nature of AssertJ to guard against regressions and catch problems early. I think it would be nice to capture this in a dedicated issue.

Example

Nothing concrete yet, but in osgi-test we are going to try and achieve it by migrating the tests for our custom AssertJ assertions to leverage the Bndtools M2E integration for running integration tests inside an OSGi framework (osgi/osgi-test#121). If it works well, perhaps we consider adding this in some form to the AssertJ build.

node.title: OSGi: Soft proxies not working on Java 9+
node.bodyHTML:
In #1968, I made a fix to better support custom assertions in OSGi bundles being used as soft assertions. This works fine on Java 8 but does nothing for Java 9+ due to the way AssertJ selects the ClassLoadingStrategy.

https://github.com/joel-costigliola/assertj-core/blob/d80cb5c8fc9d76ed6ca4361cc40e0e42d22b1cbc/src/main/java/org/assertj/core/api/ClassLoadingStrategyFactory.java#L36-L41

In Java 8, ClassLoadingStrategy.Default.INJECTION is used. The strategy respects the class loader specified in

https://github.com/joel-costigliola/assertj-core/blob/d80cb5c8fc9d76ed6ca4361cc40e0e42d22b1cbc/src/main/java/org/assertj/core/api/SoftProxies.java#L204

But in Java 9+, ClassLoadingStrategy.UsingLookup.of(PRIVATE_LOOKUP_IN.invoke(null, assertClass, LOOKUP)) is used. This strategy uses the MethodHandles.Lookup.defineClass method which only uses the class loader defining the assertClass. That is, this strategy ignores the class loader passed to the load method above :-( So this means in Java 9+, the CompositeClassLoader is not used to define the proxy classes and they can then fail to define since certain types in AssertJ are not visible.

pullRequest.title: Add field injection to SoftAssertionsExtension

node.title: Softly/SoftAssertionsExtension revamp
node.bodyHTML:
I have a number of suggestions regarding these two extensions that I wanted to float - they could be done as separate issues but they are tightly coupled so I'm going to include them in one issue for now and we can split them up later if you feel that this is appropriate.

SoftlyExtension doesn't support custom SoftAssertionsProvider

I find the field-injection style of SoftlyExtension much preferable to parameter injections. Not only does it simplify the method signatures of the tests, but you can easily have common methods that can perform a common set of (soft) assertions on some objects without having to pass the SoftAssertions reference around. I find that in many of my SoftAssertionExtension implementations, I have a line at the top of them all that says "this.softly = softly", which is boilerplate code polluting every test. The alternative is to declare SoftAssertions as a parameter to all of the common methods too, which is even less attractive.

However, SoftlyExtension has the drawback that it is hard-coded to use SoftAssertions. This means you miss out on the ability to use

Combine SoftlyExtension and SoftAssertionsExtension

In osgi-test, we've settled upon a pattern of extensions that support both field and parameter injection. This allows them to make use of common code (eg, instantiating the object to be injected) and it makes it easier for the user as they don't have to make a special effort to remember which one to use.

I can't see any good reason not to merge these two, but perhaps someone else can. Failing that, I suggest that we merge them (which will go a significant part of the way to solving the first point). Given that SoftAssertionsExtension has been around longer, I'm going to suggest merging SoftlyExtension into it and then deprecating SoftlyExtension.

Adding API for third-party extensions

If you're using multiple soft assertion-type libraries, it is nice if you can combine the two into a common "multiple failure". This was the thrust behind #1459.

@fduminy came up with a novel way to combine it with Mockito soft verification (see https://github.com/fduminy/assertj-mockito). The only problem with this implementation is that it relies on what is effectively private API of SoftAssertionsExtension to work, as it maintains its own copy of has to reach into the extension context and peek into SoftAssertionExtension's private store to get the current soft assertion instance to re-use. It would be nice if this aspect of it was publicised so that AssertJMockitoExtension and other 3rd-party extensions can get access to the soft assertion object for the current context.

In osgi-test, we hit upon the idea of using a public static method that takes an ExtensionContext as a parameter, which is responsible for fetching the object from the store (and creating it if necessary). It is possible to use a static method because the extensions themselves are stateless (or supposed to be, anyway!) and store all of their state in the ExtensionContext.

It would be nice if these extensions offered the same ability, which would help clean up code like AssertJMockitoExtension. If we merge the two extensions, this will only need to be done once - if we do not merge them, then we could consider making one depend on the other's public static initalisation method (which would go part way to solving the first point too).

assertThat(foo).isEqualTo(foo);

assertThat(foo).hasToString(foo.toString());

pullRequest.title: Rework `StandardComparisonStrategy#areEqual` to avoid shortcuts

mergeCommit.message:
Rework `StandardComparisonStrategy#areEqual` to avoid shortcuts (#2114)

The previous behavior relied on `java.util.Objects#deepEquals`, which
performs a reference check before invoking `equals` on the first
parameter. While this it not an issue for proper implementations of
the `equals` contract, it was behaving incorrectly in case of
implementations not satisfying the reflexive property. Also, performing
the reference check outside of the `equals` implementation reduced the
overall coverage.

The tests now provide thorough regression to ensure that no shortcut is
taken, especially in case of implementations violating the contract.

nodes.message: [maven-release-plugin] prepare for next development iteration

node.title: #isEqualTo(Object other) takes invalid shortcut
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Before PR #1767 (specifically commit 76762a3664b3af2101d580355a05c6f0b3aa46cc) an object x was not automatically considered equal to itself when using BDDAssertions.assertThat(x).isEqualTo(x);
By switching from

    if (o1 == null) {
      return o2 == null;
    }
    if (o1.equals(o2)) {
      return true;
    }

to calling java.util.Objects.deepEquals(o1, o2); we end up with

    if (o1 == o2)
        return true;
    else if (o1 == null || o2 == null)
        return false;
    else
        // defaults to o1.equals(o2) if type is not an array
        return Arrays.deepEquals0(o1, 2);

This means when testing a custom equals implementation of a class, BDDAssertions doesn't actually do what we expect it to do and we may oversee bugs in the application code.

Example

// fails with assertj 3.16.1; succeeds with 3.13.2; probably broken since 13.15.1
@Test
void testEquals() {
	Object x = new Object() {
		@Override
		public boolean equals(Object other) {
			return false;
		}
	};
	BDDAssertions.assertThat(x).isNotEqualTo(x);
}

node.title: Comparing of Boxed vs. Unboxed Array broken
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Before PR #1767 (specifically commit 76762a3664b3af2101d580355a05c6f0b3aa46cc) it was possible to compare a boxed with an unboxed array.
This was because org.assertj.core.util.areEqualArrays was comparing entry by entry which took care of automatic boxing/unboxing.
This functionality is broken and I'm not sure whether this was intentional. It's causing quite some refactoring efforts on our side to upgrade and I would argue that the old behaviour was quite useful.

Example

// fails with assertj 3.16.1; succeeds with 3.13.2; probably broken since 13.15.1
@Test
void testCompareArrays() {
	long[] array1 = new long[] { 2L, 2L };
	Long[] array2 = new Long[] { 2L, 2L };
		
	BDDAssertions.assertThat(array1).isEqualTo(array2);
}

pullRequest.title: Fix #2068 isValidGetter checks if return type of method is not void

node.title: Introspection.findGetter find wrong getter method with return type void
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Introspection does not work if target class has a method that has same name as the field I like to extract but with return type void

Example

org.apache.xerces.dom.events.EventImpl event = ...
assertThat(event)
        .extracting("preventDefault")
        .asInstanceOf(InstanceOfAssertFactories.BOOLEAN)
        .isTrue();

The class EventImpl has a method

public void preventDefault()

The method findGetter of class org.assertj.core.util.introspection.Introspection will return this method as getter. Therefore, the field is not introspected at all. The found getter method will return null since it has void as return type.

To fix this the method isValidGetter should check if the given method has a return type that is not void.

Workaround

Introspection.setExtractBareNamePropertyMethods(false);

pullRequest.title: Use org.junit.ComparisonFailure when available and org.opentest4j.AssertionFailedError is not.

node.title: Make .isEqualToNormalizingXxx failures easier to analyze.
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

IntelliJ IDEA (and most likely other IDEs) have a nice support for org.junit.ComparisonFailure, where it process the exception and generate a nice report with the diff, which I find very useful when comparing large objects. isEqualTo () will already throw this error. I believe all isEqualToNormalizingXxxx methods should do the same instead of throwing a raw AssertionError.

Example

Compare the result of the below (failling) tests in IntelliJ:

public class AssertionFailureTest {

  @Test
  public void isEqualTo () {
    String expected = IntStream.range (0, 200)
      .mapToObj (String::valueOf)
      .collect (Collectors.joining ("\n"));
    String actual = IntStream.range (0, 200)
      .filter (i -> i != 42)
      .mapToObj (String::valueOf)
      .collect(Collectors.joining ("\n"));

    assertThat (actual).isEqualTo (expected);
  }

  @Test
  public void isEqualToNormalizingXxxx () {
    String expected = IntStream.range (0, 200)
      .mapToObj (String::valueOf)
      .collect (Collectors.joining ("\n"));
    String actual = IntStream.range (0, 200)
      .filter (i -> i != 42)
      .mapToObj (String::valueOf)
      .collect(Collectors.joining ("\n"));

    assertThat (actual).isEqualToNormalizingNewlines (expected);
  }

}

NB

The goal of this issue is to make it easy to find the issue in case an assertion fails. Throwing a ComparisonFailure seems me to be an easy way to do that, but feel free to suggest any other way.

pullRequest.title: Fix StackOverflowError when usingRecursiveComparison of Path on Windows

node.title: StackoverflowError when usingRecursiveComparison for an Object with a nio path
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

I get a StackoverflowError when usingRecursiveComparison for an Object which contains a nio path.

Example

import org.assertj.core.api.Assertions;
import org.junit.jupiter.api.Test;

import java.nio.file.Path;
import java.nio.file.Paths;

public class AssertJBugReport {

    @Test
    public void pathThrowsStackoverflowError() {
        final Container container1 = new Container("/tmp/example");
        final Container container2 = new Container("/tmp/example");

        Assertions.assertThat(container1)
                .usingRecursiveComparison()
                .isEqualTo(container2);
    }

    public static class Container {
        private Path path;

        public Container(String path) {
            this.path = Paths.get(path);
        }

        public Path getPath() {
            return path;
        }
    }

}

pullRequest.title: StringAssert: Add method to assert equality of normalized strings

node.title: StringAssert: Add method to assert equality of normalized strings
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Some Strings look equal but their canonical form is not equal. For example one can compose the A umlaut () with a single character: \u00C4 Or with a combination of the A character and the dots (the dieresis character ): \u0041\u0308

In essence, you are using two unicode characters for one letter. Because equals() compares characters, the form with dieresis is not equals to the form without.

The problem is explained here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27670249/string-comparison-is-wrong/27670613#27670613

Example

assertThat("\u00C4").isEqualToNormalizingUnicode("\u0041\u0308")

pullRequest.title: Starting work for CollectionAssert

node.title: `isUnmodifiable` assertion for Collections
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Considering the java.util.Collections.unmodifiableXXX() methods, we could add a isUnmodifiable() method to the assert classes for collections.

Implementation Proposal

Under the hood, the assertion should try to call all the collection APIs which are expected to throw UnsupportedOperationException. The assertion succeeds if all of them are throwing the expected exception, otherwise it fails.

We could define a new AbstractCollectionAssert which would inherit from AbstractIterableAssert and would be the parent class for all the other assert classes for collection subtypes. AbstractCollectionAssert would expose isUnmodifiable(). Also, Assertions.assertThat(Collection) and BDDAssertions.then(Collection) would be needed.

Below is the mapping between the collection type and the APIs to test. Each subtype would cover also the methods of the parent type. E.g., if we have a List, the assertion should also verify Collection methods.

Instance Of APIs to test
Collection add(E), addAll(Collection), clear(), iterator().remove(), remove(Object), removeAll(Collection), removeIf(Predicate), retainAll(Collection)
List add(int, E), addAll(int, Collection), listIterator().add(E), listIterator().remove(), listIterator().set(E), remove(int), replaceAll(UnaryOperator), set(int, E), sort(Comparator)
NavigableSet descendingIterator().remove(), pollFirst(), pollLast()
Set -
SortedSet -

Example

List<Integer> list = Collections.unmodifiableList(Arrays.asList(1, 2, 3));
assertThat(list).isUnmodifiable();

node.title: Add isNotFinite and isNotInfinite for floating-point types (double, float)
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

isFinite() and isInfinite() assertions were handily added via #2005. In the comments on PR #2006, it looks like the original author believed isNotFinite() and isNotInfinite() were unnecessary, perhaps because they appear to be opposites.

However, Double.isFinite() and Double.isInfinite() (and corresponding Float methods) aren't exact opposites. isFinite() means:

  • Not POSITIVE_INFINITY, and
  • Not NEGATIVE_INFINITY, and
  • Not NaN

isInfinite() means:

  • POSITIVE_INFINITY, or
  • NEGATIVE_INFINITY

While it's possible to achieve the same result as isNotInfinite() with isNotEqualTo(Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY).isNotEqualTo(Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY), that's a little cumbersome.

isNotFinite() is much trickier to achieve--the best I've been able to do is satisfiesAnyOf(...), but that's very cumbersome, indeed.

node.title: Assertions ignore missing entry on maps
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

A custom assertion extending MapAssert that performs a org.assertj.core.api.AbstractObjectAssert.hasFieldOrProperty(String) on an actual that neither has a getter or field, but is a Map silently ignores missing map entries.

Example

Given JSON:

{
  "startLevel" : 1,
  "initialBundleStartLevel" : 1
}

The following will silently succeed

net.javacrumbs.jsonunit.assertj.JsonAssertions.assertThatJson(
    json
).isObject().hasFieldOrProperty(
    "lastModified"
);

Reason

The method org.assertj.core.util.introspection.PropertyOrFieldSupport.getSimpleValue(String, Object) throws in the case of propertySupport not having a getter method, and fieldSupport not finding a field. However in the case of the Map fallback it does not fail for a missing entry.

    // try to get name as a property, then try as a field, then try as a map key
    try {
      return propertySupport.propertyValueOf(name, Object.class, input);
    } catch (IntrospectionError propertyIntrospectionError) {
      // no luck as a property, let's try as a field
      try {
        return fieldSupport.fieldValue(name, Object.class, input);
      } catch (IntrospectionError fieldIntrospectionError) {
        // neither field nor property found with given name

        // if the input object is a map, try name as a map key
        if (input instanceof Map) {
          Map<?, ?> map = (Map<?, ?>) input;
          return map.get(name);
        }

        // no value found with given name, it is considered as an error
        String message = format("%nCan't find any field or property with name '%s'.%n" +
                                "Error when introspecting properties was :%n" +
                                "- %s %n" +
                                "Error when introspecting fields was :%n" +
                                "- %s",
                                name, propertyIntrospectionError.getMessage(),
                                fieldIntrospectionError.getMessage());
        throw new IntrospectionError(message, fieldIntrospectionError);
      }
    }

node.bodyHTML:
Summary

I think it will be convenient to have in AbstractDateAssert method isBetween(start: Instant, end: Instant) because Data and Instant are the same in meaning (unix time moment). But it's more comfortable to calculate times as Instant and don't use Date.from() to convert.

Example

pullRequest.title: Satisfies exactly in any order

node.title: Consumer-based "satisfyExactlyInAnyOrder" assertions for elements in arrays and iterables
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Based on #1621, extend the assertions API for arrays and iterables with a satisfyExactlyInAnyOrder method accepting multiple Consumer<? super ELEMENT>s.
The tested collection must have the same size as the consumers. For each element of the tested collection the (remaining) consumers are called; if a consumer accepts the element, then the element and that consumer are removed from their collections and the next element is probed.

The additional method would have the signature:

public final SELF satisfyExactlyInAnyOrder(Consumer<? super ELEMENT>... consumers)

Additionally, the method would be overloaded with an assert factory as first parameter and consumers operating not on the collection ELEMENT but on an assertion over that element (as suggested by @jbytecoder):

public final <A extends AbstractAssert<?, ELEMENT>> 
SELF satisfyExactlyInAnyOrder(Function<ELEMENT, A> assertFactory, Consumer<? super A>... consumers)

Note: the implementation from #1892 (originally for the satisfy method, aka. containsElementsSatisfyingExactlyInAnyOrder, still pending agreement on clear naming) already performs all necessary logic. It could be combined with a simple length verification.

Example

assertThat(trilogy).satisfyExactlyInAnyOrder(movie -> {
    // the fellowship of the Ring
    assertThat(movie.getReleaseDate()).isBefore(parse("2002-12-17"));
    assertThat(movie.xrated).isFalse();
  }, 
  movie -> {
    // the Return of the King
    assertThat(movie.getTitle()).endsWith("King");
  },
  movie -> {
    // the two Towers
     assertThat(movie.getReleaseDate()).isEqualTo(parse("2002-12-18"));
     assertThat(movie.getTitle()).contains("Towers");
  } 
);

assertThat(movieTitles).satisfyExactlyInAnyOrder(
  Assertions::assertThat,
  s -> s.matches(".* Return .* King"),
  s -> s.endsWith("Towers"), 
  s -> s.contains("fellowship")
);

This issue (and #2053) was split from #1621 as suggested by @joel-costigliola in #1621 (comment)

node.title: Remove space in default error message for ShouldBeEqual to help IntelliJ diff detection
node.bodyHTML:
Referencing this StackOverflow ticket: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/10934743/formatting-output-so-that-intellij-idea-shows-diffs-for-two-texts

It seems that IntelliJ expects assertion errors to be in this format in order to have nicely rendered diffs:

expected: xxx but was: yyy

But AssertJ would format this with an extra space after the was:

expected: xxx but was : yyy

Which would cause it to fail the regex, and IntelliJ defaults to just printing the error string. I tried patching my AssertJ ShouldBeEqual locally without that extra space, and IntelliJ was then able to detect it properly.

Would it be possible to remove the extraneous space after the was so that the test output can automatically be detected as a diff?

Thanks!

Link to message: https://github.com/assertj/assertj-core/blob/main/src/main/java/org/assertj/core/error/ShouldBeEqual.java#L44

pullRequest.title: Implementing `hasExactlyElementsOfTypes` mentioned in issue #1907

node.title: Verify type of element in iterable with order in mind
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Create new assertion on AbstractIterableAssert that verifies type of each element of iterable taking order into consideration.

Example

I am working currently with following code where it's important to verify that elements are of correct type in particular order:

List<CredentialsProvider> credentialsProviders = ....;

assertThat(credentialsProviders).hasSize(3);		
assertThat(credentialsProviders.get(0)).isInstanceOf(AWSStaticCredentialsProvider.class);
assertThat(credentialsProviders.get(1)).isInstanceOf(EC2ContainerCredentialsProviderWrapper.class);
assertThat(credentialsProviders.get(2)).isInstanceOf(ProfileCredentialsProvider.class);

Initial though was to replace these 3 lines with

assertThat(credentialsProviders).hasOnlyElementsOfTypes(AWSStaticCredentialsProvider.class, EC2ContainerCredentialsProviderWrapper.class, ProfileCredentialsProvider.class);

but it does not verify the order of types.

My idea is to create an assertion that would verify if all elements of an iterable match given type like:

assertThat(credentialsProviders).containsOnlyElementsOfTypes(AWSStaticCredentialsProvider.class, EC2ContainerCredentialsProviderWrapper.class, ProfileCredentialsProvider.class);

I am happy to implement it if you confirm it's a good idea or propose another solution to the problem
