node.title: Wrong collection type in Set assertion
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

The assertion error displays the wrong collection type, as noticed by @Patouche.

Example

import org.assertj.core.api.Assertions;
import org.junit.jupiter.api.Test;

import java.util.Set;
import java.util.stream.Collectors;
import java.util.stream.Stream;

class AssertJTests {

    @Test
    void iterable_bad_name() {
        final Set<String> actual = Stream.of("toto", "tata").collect(Collectors.toSet());
        Assertions.assertThat(actual).contains("tutu");
    }
}

The error is as follows:

java.lang.AssertionError: 
Expecting ArrayList:
 <["toto", "tata"]>
to contain:
 <["tutu"]>
but could not find the following element(s):
 <["tutu"]>

ArrayList should not be displayed in the error message.

pullRequest.title: CompositeRepresentation and CompositeRepresentation_Test draft.

node.title: Fine-grained Representations
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

I have recently discovered the Representation API. I am looking at using it with osgi-test and with idempiere-test as part of their respective domain-specific assertion libraries, so that they can produce more readable diagnostics by overriding toString() implementations in the domain objects.

For maximum usability and code readability, It would be nice if these Representation implementations could be auto-registered. AssertJ already provides a mechanism for this.

However, ideally, different domain-specific libraries would be able to independently register Representation implementations for their specific settings osgi-test and idempiere-test could independently register Representation implementations for their respective domains. For example, osgi-test could register a Representation implementation for the type org.osgi.framework.Bundle while idempiere-test could register one for org.compiere.model.MInvoice.

Unfortunately, with the current implementation, the default Representation implementation is a global singleton setting that is applied to all objects.

Proposal

I'm open to ideas. I'm thinking something along these lines:

  1. Un-deprecate the ServiceLoader implementation of Representation. Configuration is by nature a singleton instance and not well-suited to the modular, multi-implementation approach being offered.
  2. Representation will become parameterized. Thus:
public interface Representation<T> {
  String toStringOf(T object);
  String unambiguousToStringOf(T object);

Specific implementations of Representation can add their own bounds, eg:

public class BundleRepresentation implements Representation<Bundle> {
...
}
  1. AssertJ Core will collate all of the implementations and build a lookup table from object type to representation. This will be used by the core in determining which representation to use (if not overridden by a call to usingReperesentation()).

I think it will be possible to build the lookup table with no further changes to Representation, using reflection to find out the bound on T. However, if it is not possible, then add a supportedType() method to Representation that the core can interrogate:

public interface Representation<T> {
  String toStringOf(T object);
  String unambiguousToStringOf(T object);
  default Class<T> supportedType() {return (Class<T>)Object.class; }

pullRequest.title: Add stack trace information for Throwable when hasCauseInstanceOf and hasCauseExactlyInstanceOf fails

node.title: Describe actual Throwables when ThrowableAssert fails
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

When some Throwable-related assertion fails the actual Throwable that failed the check is not described beyond what actually caused assertion failure (e.g. message mismatch). In non trivial code when unexpected Exceptions are thrown this makes debugging inconvenient.

Dumping more comprehensive (class, message, stack, perhaps even recursive info about causes) info about the actual Throwable could ease assertion failure investigation.

Relevant message factories (e.g. ShouldHaveMessage) already have access to actual Throwable.

It may be tempting to use util.Throwables.ERROR_DESCRIPTION_EXTRACTOR to describe throwables, but more powerful mechanism would be appreciated.
Providing a precise information in case of assertion failure doesn't seem to be overkill (unlike as in #864)

Error message to improve

  • ShouldHaveCause
  • ShouldHaveCauseExactlyInstance
  • ShouldHaveCauseInstance
  • ShouldHaveCauseReference - @weiyilei
  • ShouldHaveNoCause
  • ShouldHaveNoSuppressedExceptions
  • ShouldHaveRootCauseExactlyInstance
  • ShouldHaveRootCauseInstance
  • ShouldHaveSuppressedException
  • ShouldNotContainCharSequence
  • ShouldStartWith
  • ShouldEndWith

If you are interested contributing to this issue, select one error message, it will be assigned to you.

pullRequest.title: fix issue 971:to have ability to ignore all assert when expected value is null

node.title: New Feature: to have ability to ignore all assert when expected value is null
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

to have ability to ignore all assert when expected value is null.

Example

Let's call the new method "ignoreAssertWhenExpectedIsNull"

assertThat("Hello World!").ignoreAssertWhenExpectedIsNull().isEqualTo(null); // will pass

Further more

If go further, we could have a method as ignoreAssertWhen(IgnoreType ignoreType)

Above would be

assertThat("Hello World!").ignoreAssertWhen(IgnoreType.ExpectedIsNull).isEqualTo(null); // will pass

IgnoreType could contains

  • ExpectedIsNull
  • ActualIsNull
  • EitherIsNull

pullRequest.title: Fix 'toString' method of subclasses of AtomicReference isn't used for

node.title: 'toString' method of subclasses of AtomicReference isn't used for presentation
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Sometimes we extend AtomicReference in our classes to store some internal data. (Of course, usually it's better to use delegation instead of inheritance, but it may increase memory footprint and it may be undesirable in some cases.) StandardRepresentation.toStringOf returns special representation for instances of such classes, which doesn't include result of 'toString' call.

Example

Consider the following class

class MyData extends AtomicReference<String> {
  private String description;

  MyData(String description) {
    this.description = description;
  }

  @Override
  public String toString() {
    return "MyData[" + description + "]";
  }
}

If you use its instances in assertions like

    assertThat(new MyData[] {new MyData("foo")}).contains(new MyData("bar"));

you'll get error messages like

Expecting MyData[]:
[AtomicReference[null]]
to contain:
[AtomicReference[null]]
but could not find the following mydata(s):
[AtomicReference[null]]

which aren't helpful.

pullRequest.title: isHTTPReachable

node.title: Add `isReachable` / `isUnreachable` for URL assertions
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Inspired by junit-pioneer/junit-pioneer#468, isReachable / isUnreachable assertions could be added to AbstractUrlAssert.

One of the most valuable use cases could be when the assertion is used as an assumption, allowing to skip a test if a remote dependency is not available.

The assertion name could be generic enough (i.e., not strictly bound to HTTP) and internally we could have different behaviors based on the protocol.

At first, the target should be only HTTP URLs.

This gist might inspire the assertion implementation.

Example

assertThat(new URL("http://google.com")).isReachable();
assertThat(new URL("http://invalid")).isUnreachable();

Points to discuss

  • Naming: isReachable good enough, especially if we want to have it generic? What about isAccessible or exists?
  • Testing: MockServer? Something else?
  • Should we support HTTPS? We might need to disable certificate chain and hostname validation
  • Method: GET vs HEAD
  • What to do with redirects

pullRequest.title: fix issue 2210

node.title: `hasAllNullFieldsOrProperties` and primitive types
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

hasAllNullFieldsOrProperties check that the actual object has only null fields or properties.

All fields and properties are inspected but fields with primitive types always will have some value.

Example

    class Book {
        String title;
        int pages;
    }

    @Test
    void testHasAllNullFieldsOrProperties() {
        Book book = new Book();
        assertThat(book).hasAllNullFieldsOrProperties();
    }

test will fail because of field pages is not null.

Proposition

Exclude by default all field with primitive types from assertion.

node.title: Feature: test whether two URLs represent the same primary resource
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

If the two URLs are equal after their fragments are removed and their query parameters are sorted, it means that they represent the same resource. And in the view of the server, these two URLs are almost the same. I think this feature can be useful.

See: Wikipedia: Fragment identifier
#1796 :query parameters

Example

URL actualUrl = new URL("http:example.com/a/b?c=d&e=f#1");
URL expectedUrl = new URL("http:example.com/a/b?e=f&c=d#2");
Assertions.assertThat(actualUrl).representSamePrimaryResource(expectedUrl);

Maybe the name of the assertion can be discussed.

pullRequest.title: Mark all possible public methods leading to heap pollution with `@SafeVarargs` and make them final

node.title: Using softAssertions with extracting leads to warning related to unchecked generics array creation for varargs parameter
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

When I use SoftAssertions combined with extracting, my IDE complains with the following warning

Unchecked generics array creation for varargs parameter

When I use the same code with standard Assertions, the warning is not there.

Example

With warning

    TolkienCharacter legolas = TolkienCharacter.of("Legolas", 1000, ELF);

    softly.assertThat(legolas)
          .extracting(TolkienCharacter::getName, TolkienCharacter::getAge)
          .contains("Legolas", 1000);

Without warning

    TolkienCharacter legolas = TolkienCharacter.of("Legolas", 1000, ELF);

    assertThat(legolas)
          .extracting(TolkienCharacter::getName, TolkienCharacter::getAge)
          .contains("Legolas", 1000);

pullRequest.title: add the feature mentioned in #2198

node.title: Feature Request: `assertThat(file).doesNotHaveContent("string")`
node.bodyHTML:
Currently it is possible to conveniently check a file's content with hasContent, but not the opposite.

Also I'm regularly bumping into the absence of the possibility to directly analyse files as it is possible for strings, so to have something analogous to assertThat("String").contains & doesNotContain. Of course one can do assertThat(FileUtils.readFileToString(file)) but having syntactic sugar in assertJ to avoid this would be lovely as the brevity and clarity assertJ enables is one of it's main strengths IMHO.
These last two may be a separate feature request, however i wanted to gather general feedback about feasibility first.

node.title: exclusion non existing fields, properties
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

We can exclude fields, properties from some of checking like in ObjectAssert#hasNoNullFieldsOrPropertiesExcept, RecursiveComparisonAssert#ignoringFields (maybe in other place also)

We can misspell in field name or filed can be removed from object in future development, so assertions in this situation should fail with message that excluded filed not exist.

Example

    class Book {
        String title;
    }

   Book aBook = ...

   assertThat(aBook).hasNoNullFieldsOrPropertiesExcept("name");

Assertions should fail because class Book not contains field name

pullRequest.title: implement matches() in issue #2081

node.title: Add assertions for java.util.regex.Matcher?
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Add custom assertions for java.util.regex.Matcher.

Example

java.util.Pattern pattern = ...;
String input = ...;
java.util.regex.Mather matcher = Pattern.matcher(input);
assertThat(matcher).matches()
    .hasGroupCount(1);
    (
        .extractingGroup()
        .extractingGroup(index)
        .extractingGroup(name)
    )
    .isEqualTo("some");

node.title: Add functionality to append supplied String (or Supplier<String>) to default error message
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Currently we can call withFailMessage with either a String or Supplier<String> parameter. This is nice but the default error message can be useful along with a custom error message. Please add this kind of method with both String and Supplier<String> signatures.

Thanks for the consideration!

Example

// logs "Inconceivable!" only
Assertions.assertThat("string").withFailMessage("Inconceivable!").contains("sub");
/** Would log the following:
Expecting:
 <"string">
to contain:
 <"sub">
Inconceivable!
 */
Assertions.assertThat("string").withAdditionalFailMessage("Inconceivable!").contains("sub");

// currently I am effecting this with the following workaround method...I'm guessing it's a bit of a rig
private static void assertThatTextContainsContent(final String text, final String description,
		final Supplier<String> additionalErrorMessageSupplier, final String... requiredContents) {
	try {
		final AbstractStringAssert<? extends AbstractStringAssert<?>> contentAssert =
				Assertions.assertThat(text).describedAs(description);
		Strings.instance().assertContains(contentAssert.getWritableAssertionInfo(), text, requiredContents);
	} catch (final AssertionError ae) {
		throw new AssertionError(
				String.format("%s%n%s", ae.getMessage().trim(), additionalErrorMessageSupplier.get()));
	}
}

junit 5.7.0

        softly.assertThat("b").isEqualTo("a");

pullRequest.title: fix issue 971:to have ability to ignore all assert when expected value is null

node.title: New Feature: to have ability to ignore all assert when expected value is null
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

to have ability to ignore all assert when expected value is null.

Example

Let's call the new method "ignoreAssertWhenExpectedIsNull"

assertThat("Hello World!").ignoreAssertWhenExpectedIsNull().isEqualTo(null); // will pass

Further more

If go further, we could have a method as ignoreAssertWhen(IgnoreType ignoreType)

Above would be

assertThat("Hello World!").ignoreAssertWhen(IgnoreType.ExpectedIsNull).isEqualTo(null); // will pass

IgnoreType could contains

  • ExpectedIsNull
  • ActualIsNull
  • EitherIsNull

pullRequest.title: Fix containsSubsequence failing when multiple empty subsequence.

node.title: containsSubsequence fails to check presence of multiple EMPTY Strings
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

containsSubsequence should not fail to check presence of multiple EMPTY Strings in EMPTY String

Example

import org.assertj.core.api.Assertions;
import org.testng.annotations.Test;

public class T {

    @Test
    public void test(){
        Assertions.assertThat("")
            .containsSubsequence("") // passes
            .containsSubsequence("", ""); // fails
    }
}
java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException: String index out of range: -1

	at java.base/java.lang.String.substring(String.java:1837)
	at org.assertj.core.internal.Strings.removeUpTo(Strings.java:1049)
	at org.assertj.core.internal.Strings.assertContainsSubsequence(Strings.java:1038)
	at org.assertj.core.api.AbstractCharSequenceAssert.containsSubsequence(AbstractCharSequenceAssert.java:769)

pullRequest.title: Make map containsAllEntriesOf assertion pass on empty other map

node.title: MapAssert::containsAllEntriesOf fails for non-empty actual and empty other map
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

MapAssert::containsAllEntriesOf throws assertion error for non empty actual and empty other map:

java.lang.AssertionError: actual is not empty

	at org.assertj.core.internal.Maps.failIfEmptySinceActualIsNotEmpty(Maps.java:884)
	at org.assertj.core.internal.Maps.assertContains(Maps.java:350)
	at org.assertj.core.api.AbstractMapAssert.containsAllEntriesOf(AbstractMapAssert.java:580)
        // ...

Shouldn't this succeed as it does contain all 0 entries in the expected map? IMHO this would be more consistent with #2013 and non empty check should be explicit.

Example

Map<Ring, TolkienCharacter> ringBearers = new HashMap<>();
ringBearers.put(nenya, galadriel);
ringBearers.put(narya, gandalf);
ringBearers.put(vilya, elrond);
ringBearers.put(oneRing, frodo);

Map<Ring, TolkienCharacter> octopusRingBearers = new HashMap<>();

// java.lang.AssertionError: actual is not empty
assertThat(ringBearers).containsAllEntriesOf(octopusRingBearers);

pullRequest.title: Do not create new map when testing for containsOnly and containsOnlyKeys for maps

node.title: Map `containsOnly` assertions don't work correctly with case insensitive keys
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

When using case insensitive maps the map assertions for containsOnly are not working correctly.
The reason for this is due to the fact that the actual map is copied into a LinkedHashMap and thus the checks are not using the map.

Example

Map<String, String> map = new LinkedCaseInsensitiveMap<>();
map.put("TEST", "value");

The following assertions will pass

assertThat(map).containsKey("test");
assertThat(map).contains(entry("test", "value"));

The following assertions will fail

assertThat(map).containsOnlyKeys("test");
assertThat(map).containsOnly(entry("test", "value"));

Note: LinkedCaseInsensitiveMap is from Spring.

If you agree I can work on a PR to change the mechanism that is used for validating containsOnly entries.

pullRequest.title: Prevent compiler warning when using extracting with SoftAssertions

node.title: Using softAssertions with extracting leads to warning related to unchecked generics array creation for varargs parameter
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

When I use SoftAssertions combined with extracting, my IDE complains with the following warning

Unchecked generics array creation for varargs parameter

When I use the same code with standard Assertions, the warning is not there.

Example

With warning

    TolkienCharacter legolas = TolkienCharacter.of("Legolas", 1000, ELF);

    softly.assertThat(legolas)
          .extracting(TolkienCharacter::getName, TolkienCharacter::getAge)
          .contains("Legolas", 1000);

Without warning

    TolkienCharacter legolas = TolkienCharacter.of("Legolas", 1000, ELF);

    assertThat(legolas)
          .extracting(TolkienCharacter::getName, TolkienCharacter::getAge)
          .contains("Legolas", 1000);

node.title: Add `containsAnyOf` to `CharSequence` assertions
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Currently, checking if a String contains at least one substring can be done with satisfiesAnyOf or containsPattern. The former is quite verbose, while the latter does not provide specific details in case of failures.

To improve this use case, containsAnyOf(CharSequence...) could be added to AbstractCharSequenceAssert.

Inspired by https://stackoverflow.com/q/68643040/9714611

Example

satisfiesAnyOf
assertThat("I am a string").satisfiesAnyOf(s -> assertThat(s).contains("am"),
                                           s -> assertThat(s).contains("some string"));

Failure message:

Multiple Failures (2 failures)
-- failure 1 --
Expecting actual:
  "I a string"
to contain:
  "am" 
-- failure 2 --
Expecting actual:
  "I a string"
to contain:
  "some string"
containsPattern
assertThat("I am a string").containsPattern(".(?:am|some string).*");

Failure message:

Expecting actual:
  "I a string"
to contain pattern:
  ".(?:am|some string).*"
containsAnyOf
assertThat("I am a string").containsAnyOf("am", "some string");

Failure message:

Expecting actual:
  "I a string"
to contain any of:
  ["am", "some string"]

pullRequest.title: Configure assumption exception

node.title: Allow configuring the order of assumption exception classes
node.bodyHTML:
Problem

Our project has dependencies on both JUnit5 and TestNG. Most test cases are written by JUnit5.
Assumptions.assumeThat() is also used with JUnit5. TestNG is only used for running Reactive Streams TCK.
https://github.com/reactive-streams/reactive-streams-jvm/blob/899f17ffc2927bf89fad73dfde182f5018359bdf/tck/build.gradle#L19
When I tried to upgrade AssertJ from 3.17.1, our JUnit test suits failed with:

FlagsTest > epollAvailableOnLinux() FAILED
    org.testng.SkipException: assumption was not met due to: 
    Expecting:
      ...

The error seems to be caused by the change of the order of assumption exceptions in cf65f6a.

Suggestion

It would be nice to give an option that changes the order of assumption exceptions using a property file or a JVM system property.

-Dorg.assertj.assumeption.exceptions=org.opentest4j.TestAbortedException,org.testng.SkipException,org.junit.AssumptionViolatedException

nodes.message: Use setup-java cache support

node.title: hasMethods does not work on default methods
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

IMO hasMethod should really follow the same contract as Class.getMethod(), but it doesn't when it comes to default methods inherited from an interface (that are not overridden with an implementation in the class being asserted).

This is because org.assertj.core.internal.Classes.getAllMethods(Class<?>) only looks at parent classes and not any implemented interfaces.

Example

class DefaultHasMethodTest {

  interface HasDefault {
    default void method() {}
  }

  static class Impl implements HasDefault {
  }

  @Test
  void testHasMethod() throws Exception {
    assertThat(Impl.class).hasMethods("method");
  }
}

This might be related to #880.

pullRequest.title: Improve assertion error for hasSameElementsAs(emptyList())

node.title: nondescript assertion error for hasSameElementsAs(emptyList())
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Compared to other asserts, hasSameElementsAs has only a brief and generic assertion error given an empty expected collection.

Example

    List<String> actual = List.of("element");
    Assertions.assertThat(actual).as("helpful message").hasSameElementsAs(Collections.emptyList());

fails with

java.lang.AssertionError: actual is not empty

In comparision

    List<String> actual = List.of("element");
    Assertions.assertThat(actual).as("helpful message").containsExactlyElementsOf(Collections.emptyList());

has a much richer message as I would expect from AssertJ:

java.lang.AssertionError: [helpful message] 
Expecting actual:
  ["element"]
to contain exactly (and in same order):
  []
but some elements were not expected:
  ["element"]

pullRequest.title: File size assert

node.title: Additional File Assertions
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

At the moment, it's possible to check file sizes using the file assertions (see #1311), but it's not possible to check if a file is bigger or smaller than a certain size. I'd propose to add these assertions too, and match the signature with the collection assertions, like this.

Example

assertThat(file).hasSizeBetween(1_000_000, 2_000_000));
assertThat(file).hasGreaterThan(1_000_000));
assertThat(file).hasLessThanOrEqual(2_000_000));
// etc

I'm willing to do a PR for this, but I'd like to know first if this is something which would be welcome in AssertJ, or not.

pullRequest.title: Fix #2296 : 2D arrays - assert size of first dimension only

node.title: 2D arrays: assert size of first dimension only
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

In assertj 3.17.0, for 2D arrays like byte[][] the hasSize(int) method has been replaced by hasDimensions(int, int).

It would be useful to keep the hasSize(int) as well. The length of the second dimension might be different for each entry, or it might simply be irrelevant to the test.

Example

assertThat(bytes).hasDimensions(3, /* problem: second dimension is variable length */);

node.title: `ThrowableAssert` should have a type parameter
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Currently assertThatExceptionOfType allows chaining type-specific assertions like extracting(Function), but assertThat with an instance of the same exception type does not allow chaining them.

Example

Having an exception type like:

class MyException extends RuntimeException {

    private final int field;

    MyException(int field) {
        this.field = field;
    }

    int getField() {
        return field;
    }

}

The following works:

assertThatExceptionOfType(MyException.class).isThrownBy(() -> doSomething())
    .extracting(MyException::getField)
    .isEqualTo(10);

but the following does not:

MyException myException = catchThrowableOfType(() -> doSomething(), MyException.class);

assertThat(myException)
    .extracting(MyException::getField) // does not compile
    .isEqualTo(10);

Adding a type parameter to ThrowableAssert should fix the issue. E.g.:

public class ThrowableAssert<ACTUAL extends Throwable> extends AbstractThrowableAssert<ThrowableAssert<ACTUAL>, ACTUAL> {
   // implementation
}

node.title: Regression in `AbstractMapAssert#containsExactlyInAnyOrderEntriesOf`
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

After upgrading from assertj 3.19.0 to 3.20.0 (and 3.20.1), I am seeing tests fail using org.assertj.core.api.AbstractMapAssert#containsExactlyInAnyOrderEntriesOf where the map value is a byte array (e.g. Map<String, byte[]>.

This appears to have broken in #2167 specifically with the use of Map.remove(Object, Object) that does not perform deep equality checking on the map entry value (e.g. arrays).

Example

Adding the following test to org.assertj.core.api.map.MapAssert_containsExactlyInAnyOrderEntriesOf_Test against assertj-core-3.19.0 passes, but fails on assertj-core-3.20.0, assertj-core-3.20.1, and main

  @Test
  void invoke_api_like_user_with_value_array() {

    // GIVEN
    Map<String, byte[]> actualMap = mapOf(entry("key1", new byte[]{1, 2}),
      entry("key2", new byte[]{3, 4, 5}));
    Map<String, byte[]> expectedMap = mapOf(entry("key2", new byte[]{3, 4, 5}),
      entry("key1", new byte[]{1, 2}));
    // THEN
    assertThat(actualMap).containsExactlyInAnyOrderEntriesOf(expectedMap);
  }

With output:

java.lang.AssertionError: 
Expecting map:
  {"key1"=[1, 2], "key2"=[3, 4, 5]}
to contain only:
  [key2=[B@551a20d6, key1=[B@578524c3]
but the following map entries were unexpected:
  [MapEntry[key="key1", value=[1, 2]], MapEntry[key="key2", value=[3, 4, 5]]]

pullRequest.title: issue-2401 extracting should throw an assertion error if actual is null

node.title: `extracting` should throw a proper assertion error if `actual` is null
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Based on #2392 (comment) and further comments, the implementation of extracting(Function, AssertFactory) and extracting(String, AssertFactory) in AbstractAssert should be improved to ensure that a preliminary isNotNull check is performed.

Example

The following assertions:

assertThatObject(null).extracting(Object::getClass);
assertThatObject(null).extracting("class");

should fail with:

java.lang.AssertionError: 
Expecting actual not to be null

instead of failing with:

java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.assertj.core.api.AbstractAssert.extracting(AbstractAssert.java:1016)
	at org.assertj.core.api.AbstractObjectAssert.extracting(AbstractObjectAssert.java:953)
	...

and:

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: The object to extract property/field from should not be null
	at org.assertj.core.util.Preconditions.checkArgument(Preconditions.java:129)
	at org.assertj.core.util.introspection.PropertyOrFieldSupport.getValueOf(PropertyOrFieldSupport.java:49)
	at org.assertj.core.extractor.ByNameSingleExtractor.apply(ByNameSingleExtractor.java:29)
	at org.assertj.core.api.AbstractAssert.extracting(AbstractAssert.java:990)
	at org.assertj.core.api.AbstractObjectAssert.extracting(AbstractObjectAssert.java:834)
	...

respectively.

pullRequest.title: Issue 2379 map assert throws npe on null key and value

node.title: MapAssert throws NPE on null key and value
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

MapAssert throws NPE on null key and value, if Map implementation does not accept null values like java.util.Map#of(*).
For List there ist a special method ListAssert#doesNotContainNull().
Maybe MapAssert should also have special treatment for null keys and values.
At least the negative verification methods shouldn't throw an exception.

Example

assertThat(List.of("a", "b")).doesNotContainNull(); // OK

assertThat(Map.of("a", "b")).containsValue(null); // NPE
assertThat(Map.of("a", "b")).containsKey(null); // NPE

assertThat(Map.of("a", "b")).doesNotContainKey(null); // NPE
assertThat(Map.of("a", "b")).doesNotContainValue(null); // NPE

run with org.assertj:assertj-core:3.21.0

node.title: Extracting through field names not supported for optional in java 17
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

I'm upgrading to java 17 (from java 11), and I have some tests failing due to an incompatibility between java 17 and assertJ.
One of the breaking changes introduced by java 17 is JEP 396: Strongly Encapsulate JDK Internals by Default.
It seems that assertJ try to force access to non public value (not public) when extracting them through field name => extract the value from an optional ("object.value") and since the value is not public I got this exception:

org.assertj.core.util.introspection.IntrospectionError: 
Can't find any field or property with name 'value'.
Error when introspecting properties was :
- No getter for property 'value' in java.util.Optional 
Error when introspecting fields was :
- Unable to obtain the value of the field <'value'> from <Optional[john]>

	at org.assertj.core.util.introspection.PropertyOrFieldSupport.getSimpleValue(PropertyOrFieldSupport.java:88)
	at org.assertj.core.util.introspection.PropertyOrFieldSupport.getValueOf(PropertyOrFieldSupport.java:60)
	at org.assertj.core.util.introspection.PropertyOrFieldSupport.getValueOf(PropertyOrFieldSupport.java:57)
	at org.assertj.core.extractor.ByNameSingleExtractor.apply(ByNameSingleExtractor.java:29)
	at org.assertj.core.api.AbstractAssert.extracting(AbstractAssert.java:1059)
	at org.assertj.core.api.AbstractObjectAssert.extracting(AbstractObjectAssert.java:834)
	at fr.witchbird.cl.negotiation.test.functional.VersionIT.should_access(VersionIT.java:165)

	at java.base/java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:568)
	at org.junit.runners.model.FrameworkMethod$1.runReflectiveCall(FrameworkMethod.java:50)
	at org.junit.internal.runners.model.ReflectiveCallable.run(ReflectiveCallable.java:12)
	at org.junit.runners.model.FrameworkMethod.invokeExplosively(FrameworkMethod.java:47)
	at org.junit.internal.runners.statements.InvokeMethod.evaluate(InvokeMethod.java:17)
	at org.junit.runners.ParentRunner.runLeaf(ParentRunner.java:325)
	at org.junit.runners.BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.runChild(BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.java:78)
	at org.junit.runners.BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.runChild(BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.java:57)

Caused by: org.assertj.core.util.introspection.IntrospectionError: Unable to obtain the value of the field <'value'> from <Optional[john]>
	at org.assertj.core.util.introspection.FieldSupport.readSimpleField(FieldSupport.java:248)
	at org.assertj.core.util.introspection.FieldSupport.fieldValue(FieldSupport.java:202)
	at org.assertj.core.util.introspection.PropertyOrFieldSupport.getSimpleValue(PropertyOrFieldSupport.java:70)

Caused by: java.lang.reflect.InaccessibleObjectException: Unable to make field private final java.lang.Object java.util.Optional.value accessible: module java.base does not "opens java.util" to unnamed module @7fbe847c

Example

       private static class Person {
		private final Optional<String> name;

		public Person(final Optional<String> name) {
			this.name = name;

		public Optional<String> getName() {

pullRequest.title: Issue2211 has no null fields or properties recurrence

node.title: `hasNoNullFieldsOrProperties` - recurrence
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

When we have more complicated objects structure it will be useful to have possibility to check that all fields for actual object and all fields in included object are also not null.

Example

    class Author {
        String name;
        String email;

        Author(String name, String email) {
            this.name = name;
            this.email = email;
        }
    }

    class Book {
        String title;
        Author author;

        Book(String title, Author author) {
            this.title = title;
            this.author = author;
        }
    }

    @Test
    void testHasNoNullFieldsOrProperties() {
        Book book = new Book("title", new Author(null, null));
        assertThat(book).hasNoNullFieldsOrProperties();
        assertThat(book.author).hasNoNullFieldsOrProperties();
    }

assertion assertThat(book).hasNoNullFieldsOrProperties() will pass and it is true
second assertion assertThat(book.author).hasNoNullFieldsOrProperties() will fail and it is also ok.

When we have object with many other object we must write many assertions for each fields.
When we add new field to object we must also remember to add new assertion.

Proposition

assertion assertThat(book).hasNoNullFieldsOrProperties() should fail because object book.author has fields with null values.

pullRequest.title: Apply pattern to file name only with `isDirectoryContaining` / `isDirectoryNotContaining`

node.title: isDirectoryContaining fails for expected patterns
node.bodyHTML:
Let's assume that there is a directory C:\Temp\junit12854012982575283912 which contains a file test-6e672c4ba0be4f0886d434125a0d062c.txt.

The assertion of assertThat(dir).isDirectoryContaining("glob:test-[0-9a-f]*.txt") and assertThat(dir).isDirectoryContaining("regex:test-[0-9a-f]+\\.txt") fails although it is not expected do so.

The error messages is confusing and does not give a hint why this pattern would be wrong.

Expecting directory:
  C:\Temp\junit12854012982575283912\out
to contain at least one file matching the 'glob:test-[0-9a-f]*.txt' pattern but there was none.
The directory content was:
  [test-6e672c4ba0be4f0886d434125a0d062c.txt]

Using the same with a PathMatcher succeeds.

assertThat(dir.getFileSystem().getPathMatcher("glob:test-[0-9a-f]*.txt").matches(Path.of("test-6e672c4ba0be4f0886d434125a0d062c.txt"))).isTrue();
assertThat(dir.getFileSystem().getPathMatcher("regex:test-[0-9a-f]+\\.txt").matches(Path.of("test-6e672c4ba0be4f0886d434125a0d062c.txt"))).isTrue();

There is also a difference between using Path instead of File. If the directory variable is of type Path, the error outputs the absolute paths of the file in the directory. That gives a hint about what might be wrong.

Expecting directory:
  C:\Temp\junit12854012982575283912\out
to contain at least one file matching the 'glob:test-[0-9a-f]*.txt' pattern but there was none.
The directory content was:
  [C:\Temp\junit12854012982575283912\out\test-6e672c4ba0be4f0886d434125a0d062c.txt]

isDirectoryContaining tests against the absolute path of the files although it should test against their relative paths. The patterns from my example will of course never match against the absolute path! Using "glob:**test-[0-9a-f]*.txt" works but the expectation when using the API is that the paths are relative. If it is really the intention to test against the absolute path, the docs should be very clear about this.

p.s.
This example in the javadoc .isDirectoryContaining("glob:**.{ext,bin") is missing a closing "}". It should be .isDirectoryContaining("glob:**.{ext,bin}").

pullRequest.title: #2374 Accept vararg for AbstractAssert.satisfies

node.title: Add `satisfiesAllOf` to `AbstractAssert`
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

AssertJ already has support for soft assertions. However, that feature might be difficult to discover as it's not part of the main API and also a bit error-prone considering that you have to remember to call assertAll in the end.

AbstractAssert already contains a satisfiesAnyOf method, so this proposed method would be a nice complement to that. It would be easy to discover and would be less error-prone.

Example

TolkienCharacter frodo = new TolkienCharacter("Frodo", HOBBIT);
    
Consumer<TolkienCharacter> isHobbit = tolkienCharacter -> assertThat(tolkienCharacter.getRace()).isEqualTo(HOBBIT);
Consumer<TolkienCharacter> isElf = tolkienCharacter -> assertThat(tolkienCharacter.getRace()).isEqualTo(ELF);
Consumer<TolkienCharacter> isFrodo = tolkienCharacter -> assertThat(tolkienCharacter.getName()).isEqualTo("Frodo");
Consumer<TolkienCharacter> isBoromir = tolkienCharacter -> assertThat(tolkienCharacter.getRace()).isEqualTo("Boromir");
    
// assertion succeeds:
assertThat(frodo).satisfiesAllOf(isHobbit, isFrodo);
    
// assertion fails reporting all failures:
assertThat(boromir).satisfiesAllOf(isElf, isBoromir);

If the proposal is accepted I would be happy to contribute.

pullRequest.title: Fix #2366: Multiline object formatting

node.title: Create beautiful error messages for multi-line values and nested asserts
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

AssertJ error messages currently do not take into account that toString of asserted values may contain new lines.

The resulting error messages can at times look awkward due to missing indentation.

Example

For example let's consider a class where toString returns multi-line XML:

<xml>
  <value>A</value>
</xml>

For simplicity I will use the following:

  public static class Xml {
    private final String value;
    public Xml(String value) {
      this.value = value;
    }
    @Override
    public boolean equals(Object o) {
      if (this == o) return true;
      if (o == null || getClass() != o.getClass()) return false;
      Xml xml = (Xml) o;
      return Objects.equals(value, xml.value);
    }
    @Override
    public int hashCode() {
      return Objects.hash(value);
    }
    @Override
    public String toString() {
      return "<xml>\n  <value>" + value + "</value>\n</xml>";
    }
  }

  private static Xml xml(String value) {
    return new Xml(value);
  }
assertThat(xml("A")).isNull();

This will produce the following error message:

org.opentest4j.AssertionFailedError: 
expected: null
 but was: <xml>
  <value>A</value>
</xml>

Notice that the first line is awkwardly placed directly after "but was". Also notice that last line has same indentation as "expected".

This message could be improved to e.g.

org.opentest4j.AssertionFailedError: 
expected: 
  null
but was: 
  <xml>
    <value>A</value>
  </xml>

Similarly:

assertThat(xml("A")).isEqualTo(xml("B"));

currently produces the following error:

org.opentest4j.AssertionFailedError: 
expected: <xml>
  <value>B</value>
</xml>
 but was: <xml>
  <value>A</value>
</xml>

This could be improved to e.g.:

org.opentest4j.AssertionFailedError: 
expected: 
  <xml>
    <value>B</value>
  </xml>
but was: 
  <xml>
    <value>A</value>
  </xml>

Indentation becomes even more useful to decipher error messages when we use anySatisfy:

assertThat(Arrays.asList(xml("A"), xml("B"))).anySatisfy(v1 -> {
  assertThat(v1).isEqualTo(xml("C"));
});

Currently AssertJ produces:

java.lang.AssertionError: 
Expecting any element of:
  [<xml>
  <value>A</value>
</xml>, <xml>
  <value>B</value>
</xml>]
to satisfy the given assertions requirements but none did:

<xml>
  <value>A</value>
</xml>
error: 
expected: <xml>
  <value>C</value>
</xml>
 but was: <xml>
  <value>A</value>
</xml>

<xml>
  <value>B</value>
</xml>
error: 
expected: <xml>
  <value>C</value>
</xml>
 but was: <xml>
  <value>B</value>
</xml>

This could be improved to e.g.:

java.lang.AssertionError: 
Expecting any element of:
  [
    <xml>
      <value>A</value>
    </xml>
  , 
    <xml>
      <value>B</value>
    </xml>
  ]
to satisfy the given assertions requirements but none did:

  Element
    <xml>
      <value>A</value>
    </xml>
  : 
    expected: 
      <xml>
        <value>C</value>
      </xml>
    but was: 
      <xml>
        <value>A</value>
      </xml>
  
  Element
    <xml>
      <value>B</value>
    </xml>
  : 
    expected: 
      <xml>
        <value>C</value>
      </xml>
    but was: 
      <xml>
        <value>B</value>
      </xml>

The following extreme case produces very long and hard to decipher error messages.

assertThat(Arrays.asList(xml("A"), xml("B"))).anySatisfy(v1 -> {
  assertThat(Arrays.asList(xml("C"), xml("D"))).anySatisfy(v2 -> {
    assertThat(v1).isEqualTo(v2);
  });
});

I will not include the long error here but I think indentation could also help a lot here to make errors parsable by humans.

pullRequest.title: New Feature: AbstractThrowableAssert#message()  #2378

node.title: New Feature: AbstractThrowableAssert#message()
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Please add a shortcut for extracting(Throwable::getMessage, as(InstanceOfAssertFactories.STRING)) to perform assertions on an exception's message (discussed in #2376 (comment)).

Example

Instead of

assertThatThrownBy(() -> {
  /* code to test */
})
  .isInstanceOf(CertPathValidatorException.class)
  .extracting(Throwable::getMessage, as(InstanceOfAssertFactories.STRING))
  .containsAnyOf(
    "could not be determined",
    "could not determine revocation status",
    "revocation status check failed"
  );

one can then use

assertThatThrownBy(() -> {
  /* code to test */
})
  .isInstanceOf(CertPathValidatorException.class)
  .message()
  .containsAnyOf(
    "could not be determined",
    "could not determine revocation status",
    "revocation status check failed"
  );

pullRequest.title: Add AbstractThrowableAssert#causesChain to simplify performing assertions on a chain of throwables

node.title: Provide semantic ways to test n-level (n>1) causes of an Exception, not only direct cause and root cause
node.bodyHTML:
Assertj currently provides methods to test a thrown exception, its direct cause, or its root cause. It does not offer a semantic way to test the exceptions/causes in between the first cause and the root cause.

Exceptions tend to get wrapped and wrapped by frameworks and libraries, and by project code. Sometimes the most meaningful exception is neither the one thrown nor its cause nor the root cause, but one somewhere in the middle.

For example, BackendEx caused by BusinessLogicEx caused by SqlRollbackEx caused by UnableToExecuteSqlEx in a test where I just want to assert that my sql will be rolled back by finding the SqlRollbackEx in the stack.

assertThatThrownBy(() -> {}).hasAnyLevelCauseInstanceOf(type);
assertThatThrownBy(() -> {}).hasAnyLevelCauseWithMessageMatching(condition);
// etc

pullRequest.title: Print offending token in error message from containsSubsequence

node.title: Error message from `containsSubsequence` should print offending token
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

The error message from containsSubsequence should print the contents and index of the first token that was not contained in the actual value.
See the example below.
In this case, the offending token is the following line:

"@DaggerGenerated
@Generated(    value = "dagger.internal.codegen.ComponentProcessor",    comments = "https://github.com/jbock-java/dapper")
@SuppressWarnings({    "unchecked",    "rawtypes"})"

Eyeball search for the offending token is taking too long, if you have a lot of failing tests.

Example

java.lang.AssertionError: 
Expecting actual:
  ["package test;",
    "",
    "import dagger.Lazy;",
    "import dagger.internal.DaggerGenerated;",
    "import dagger.internal.DoubleCheck;",
    "import jakarta.inject.Provider;",
    "import javax.annotation.processing.Generated;",
    "",
    "@DaggerGenerated",
    "@Generated(",
    "    value = "dagger.internal.codegen.ComponentProcessor",",
    "    comments = "https://github.com/jbock-java/dapper"",
    ")",
    "@SuppressWarnings({",
    "    "unchecked",",
    "    "rawtypes"",
    "})",
    "final class DaggerSimpleComponent implements SimpleComponent {",
    "  private final DaggerSimpleComponent simpleComponent = this;",
    "",
    "  private Provider<SomeInjectableType> someInjectableTypeProvider;",
    "",
    "  private DaggerSimpleComponent() {",
    "",
    "    initialize();",
    "",
    "  }",
    "",
    "  public static Builder builder() {",
    "    return new Builder();",
    "  }",
    "",
    "  public static SimpleComponent create() {",
    "    return new Builder().build();",
    "  }",
    "",
    "  @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")",
    "  private void initialize() {",
    "    this.someInjectableTypeProvider = DoubleCheck.provider(SomeInjectableType_Factory.create());",
    "  }",
    "",
    "  @Override",
    "  public SomeInjectableType someInjectableType() {",
    "    return someInjectableTypeProvider.get();",
    "  }",
    "",
    "  @Override",
    "  public Lazy<SomeInjectableType> lazySomeInjectableType() {",
    "    return DoubleCheck.lazy(someInjectableTypeProvider);",
    "  }",
    "",
    "  @Override",
    "  public Provider<SomeInjectableType> someInjectableTypeProvider() {",
    "    return someInjectableTypeProvider;",
    "  }",
    "",
    "  static final class Builder {",
    "    private Builder() {",
    "    }",
    "",
    "    public SimpleComponent build() {",
    "      return new DaggerSimpleComponent();",
    "    }",
    "  }",
    "}"]
to contain sequence:
  ["package test;",
    "",
    "@DaggerGenerated
@Generated(    value = "dagger.internal.codegen.ComponentProcessor",    comments = "https://github.com/jbock-java/dapper")
@SuppressWarnings({    "unchecked",    "rawtypes"})",
    "final class DaggerSimpleComponent implements SimpleComponent {",
    "  private final DaggerSimpleComponent simpleComponent = this;",
    "  private Provider<SomeInjectableType> someInjectableTypeProvider;",
    "",
    "  @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")",
    "  private void initialize() {",
    "    this.someInjectableTypeProvider =",
    "        DoubleCheck.provider(SomeInjectableType_Factory.create());",
    "  }",
    "",
    "  @Override",
    "  public SomeInjectableType someInjectableType() {",
    "    return someInjectableTypeProvider.get();",
    "  }",
    "",
    "  @Override",
    "  public Lazy<SomeInjectableType> lazySomeInjectableType() {",
    "    return DoubleCheck.lazy(someInjectableTypeProvider);",
    "  }",
    "",
    "  @Override",
    "  public Provider<SomeInjectableType> someInjectableTypeProvider() {",
    "    return someInjectableTypeProvider;",
    "  }",
    "}"]

node.title: Do not shade Byte Buddy
node.bodyHTML: Byte Buddy is currently shaded. As Byte Buddy retains compatibility, not shading the library would allow running recent JVMs without an update of assertj but only BB. Other libraries like Mockito or Hibernate do not shade BB and there are no known issues with this approach. In case of an error, stack traces would also be easier to process as break points remain intact.

pullRequest.title: Issue#2381: isUnmodifiable assertion for Maps

node.title: `isUnmodifiable` assertion for Maps
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Similarly to #2102, we could add a isUnmodifiable() method to the assertion methods for Map types.

Implementation Proposal

Under the hood, the assertion should try to call all the map APIs which are expected to throw UnsupportedOperationException. The assertion succeeds if all of them are throwing the expected exception, otherwise it fails.

Below is the mapping between the map type and the APIs to test. Each subtype would cover also the methods of the parent type. E.g., if we have a NavigableMap, the assertion should also verify Map methods.

Instance Of APIs to test
Map clear(), compute(K, BiFunction), computeIfAbsent(K, Function), computeIfPresent(K, BiFunction), iterator().remove(), merge(K, V, BiFunction), put(K, V), putAll(Map), putIfAbsent(K, V), replace(K, V), replace(K, V, V), remove(Object), remove(Object, Object), replaceAll(BiFunction)
NavigableMap pollFirstEntry(), pollLastEntry()
SortedMap -

Example

Map<String, String> map = new HashMap<>();
map.put("key", "value");

assertThat(map).isUnmodifiable(); // should fail

Map<String, String> unmodifiableMap = Collections.unmodifiableMap(map);

assertThat(unmodifiableMap).isUnmodifiable(); // should succeed

node.title: isExactlyInstanceOf gives confusing error message when instance is an anonymous inner class
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

When using isExactlyInstanceOf and the actual value is an anonymous inner class, the message is confusing as it claims that the actual value is an "instance of null".

Example

    assertThat(x.red).isNotNull().isExactlyInstanceOf(A.class);

Will not fail isNotNull but fails on isExactlyInstanceOf with:

java.lang.AssertionError: 
Expecting:
 <hs.ddif.core.inject.store.BindingProvider$ProviderBinding$1@4f1bfe23>
to be exactly an instance of:
 <hs.ddif.core.InjectorProviderTest.A>
but was an instance of:
 <null>

This led me to believe the value in x.red is null, but it clearly isn't.

If it is not possible to detect the anonymous inner class type here (it in this case is an anonymous implementation of the interface Provider) perhaps change the message to but was an instance of an anonymous class.

pullRequest.title: Preliminary code to ensure AbstractMapAssert uses correct containsKey

node.title: `containsKey` in `AbstractMapAssert` overuses `containsKeys` implementation
node.bodyHTML:
Currently, containsKey of AbstractMapAssert reuses the implementation of containsKeys, wrapping the expected key in an array and getting the error message from ShouldContainKeys.

Ideally, containsKey should have its simplified implementation, backed by Maps#assertContainsKey with a dedicated error message coming from ShouldContainKey.

Almost the same situation is with doesNotContainKey and doesNotContainKeys.

pullRequest.title: Add IgnoringCase variants of startsWith and endsWith (#2449)

node.title: Add `startsWithIgnoringCase` and `endsWithIgnoringCase` to AbstractCharSequenceAssert
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

While migrating assertions from Hamcrest to AssertJ I noticed there was no AssertJ equivalent to Hamcrest's org.hamcrest.Matchers#startsWithIgnoringCase and org.hamcrest.Matchers#endsWithIgnoringCase. However, AssertJ does provide org.assertj.core.api.AbstractCharSequenceAssert#containsIgnoringCase which is equivalent to Hamcrest's org.hamcrest.Matchers#containsStringIgnoringCase, so there is precedence in providing "ignoringCase" alternatives.

Example

// assertion will pass
assertThat("Gandalf the grey").startsWithIgnoringCase("Gandalf");
assertThat("Gandalf the grey").startsWithIgnoringCase("gandalf");

//assertions will fail
assertThat("Gandalf the grey").startsWithIgnoringCase("grey");

and

// assertion will pass
assertThat("Gandalf the grey").endsWithIgnoringCase("grey");
assertThat("Gandalf the grey").endsWithIgnoringCase("Grey");

//assertions will fail
assertThat("Gandalf the grey").endsWithIgnoringCase("Gandalf");

If you agree that this would be a reasonable addition to the API, I would be happy to take first stab at implementing this.

pullRequest.title: Fix `containsExactly` not working properly with maps not using equals to compare keys

node.title: `containsExactly` does not work properly with maps not using equals to compare keys
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

This test should pass but fails.

  @Test
  void should_pass_if_case_insensitive_actual_contains_given_entries_in_rder() {
    // GIVEN
    actual = new CaseInsensitiveMap<>();
    actual.put( "Color", "green" );
    actual.put( "NAME", "Yoda" );

    // THEN
    maps.assertContainsExactly(someInfo(), actual, entry("COLOR", "green"), entry("Name", "Yoda"));
  }

The underlying issue is when containsExactly verifies that the entries are in the same order, it ends up comparing "Color" against "COLOR" with equals instead of the actual map key comparison strategy (case insensitive string in the example).

It's not yet clear if there is a way to address this issue, if not we would have to mention the limitation in the javadoc.

pullRequest.title: Fix usingRecursiveComparison with usingOverriddenEquals ignores equal

node.title: usingRecursiveComparison with usingOverriddenEquals ignores equals method of the compared object
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Version 3.22.0
I expect if I use usingRecursiveComparison with usingOverriddenEquals, field "age" should be ignored.
But as result I get

java.lang.AssertionError:
Expecting actual:
com.ComparatorDevices$Person@63be0d6
to be equal to:
com.ComparatorDevices$Person@63be0b6
when recursively comparing field by field, but found the following difference:

field/property 'age' differ:

  • actual value : "22"
  • expected value: "11"

The recursive comparison was performed with this configuration:

  • overridden equals methods were used in the comparison
  • these types were compared with the following comparators:
    • java.lang.Double -> DoubleComparator[precision=1.0E-15]
    • java.lang.Float -> FloatComparator[precision=1.0E-6]
    • java.nio.file.Path -> lexicographic comparator (Path natural order)
  • actual and expected objects and their fields were compared field by field recursively even if they were not of the same type, this allows for example to compare a Person to a PersonDto (call strictTypeChecking(true) to change that behavior).

Example

class Person {
        String name;
        String age;

        public Person(String name, String age) {
            this.name = name;
            this.age = age;
        }

        @Override
        public boolean equals(Object o) {
            if (this == o) return true;
            if (o == null || getClass() != o.getClass()) return false;
            Person person = (Person) o;
            return Objects.equals(name, person.name);
        }

        @Override
        public int hashCode() {
            return Objects.hash(name, age);
        }
    }

@Test()
    public void personTest() {
        Person expectedPerson = new Person("name", "11");
        Person actualPerson = new Person("name", "22");
        Assertions.assertThat(actualPerson)
                .usingRecursiveComparison()
                .usingOverriddenEquals()
                .isEqualTo(expectedPerson);
    }

pullRequest.title: Draft of #1652

node.title: Assert return value of callable throwing exception
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

It would be nice if the assertThatCode().doesNotThrowException() API would be able execute functions that return a value and then return that value for further inspection.
This would make it easy to provide a nice description to an otherwise maybe nondescript exception that is thrown.

Example

@Test 
public void intendedApi() {
  int x = assertThatCode(this::doStuff)
    .describedAs("doing things")
    .doesNotThrowAnyException();
  assertThat(x).isEqualTo(3);
}

@Test
public void currentSolution1() {
  int x;
  try {
    x = doStuff();
  } catch (Exception e) {
    fail("doing things");
    return; // never reached; needed because fail() is not recognized by the java compiler as method exit
  }
  assertThat(x).isEqualTo(3);
}

@Test
public void currentSolution2() {
  AtomicReference<Integer> x = new AtomicReference<>();
  assertThatCode(() -> x.set(doStuff()))
    .describedAs("doing things")
    .doesNotThrowAnyException();
  assertThat(x.get()).isEqualTo(3);
}

// utility for demonstration purposes
public int doStuff() throws Exception {
  if (new Random().nextBoolean()) {
    throw new Exception();
  }
  return 3;
}

pullRequest.title: Fixes #2459: Avoid ValueNode being considered as iterable while using recursive comparison

node.title: Different behavior between recursive comparison and JsonUnit with Jackson `JsonNode`
node.bodyHTML:
Given:

ObjectMapper om = new ObjectMapper();

JsonNode objectNode0 = om.readTree("{\"someNotImportantValue\":1,\"importantValue\":\"10\"}");
JsonNode objectNode1 = om.readTree("{\"someNotImportantValue\":15,\"importantValue\":\"1\"}");

with JsonUnit:

JsonAssertions.assertThatJson(objectNode0).isEqualTo(objectNode1);

we get a failure with:

net.javacrumbs.jsonunit.core.internal.Opentest4jExceptionFactory$JsonAssertError: JSON documents are different:
Different value found in node "importantValue", expected: <"1"> but was: <"10">.
Different value found in node "someNotImportantValue", expected: <15> but was: <1>.

but with AssertJ and recursive comparison:

assertThat(objectNode0).usingRecursiveComparison().isEqualTo(objectNode1);

the assertion passes.

Being JsonNode an Iterable, it seems that something is not working properly with AssertJ.

Source: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/70602371/assertj-not-working-with-jackson-jsonnode

pullRequest.title: Issue#2455: isStatic / isNotStatic for Class assertions

node.title: `isStatic` / `isNotStatic` for `Class` assertions

Summary

isStatic and isNotStatic could be added to Class assertions, mostly relevant for nested classes.

Example

Having:

class OuterClass {

  class InnerClass {
  }

  static class StaticNestedClass {
  }

  interface NestedInterface {
  }

}

the following assertions should pass:

assertThat(OuterClass.class).isNotStatic();
assertThat(OuterClass.InnerClass.class).isNotStatic();

assertThat(OuterClass.StaticNestedClass.class).isStatic();
assertThat(OuterClass.NestedInterface.class).isStatic();

node.title: 2D arrays: assert size of first dimension only
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

In assertj 3.17.0, for 2D arrays like byte[][] the hasSize(int) method has been replaced by hasDimensions(int, int).

It would be useful to keep the hasSize(int) as well. The length of the second dimension might be different for each entry, or it might simply be irrelevant to the test.

pullRequest.title: Add additional assertions for `CharSequence`

node.title: Additional assertions for `CharSequence`
node.bodyHTML:
Using the existing matches(Pattern) and POSIX regex character classes, we can add specialized assertions to AbstractCharSequenceAssert.

assertThat(string).isAlphabetic();   // \p{Alpha}
assertThat(string).isAlphanumeric(); // \p{Alnum}
assertThat(string).isASCII();        // \p{ASCII}
assertThat(string).isDigit();        // \p{Digit}
assertThat(string).isHexadecimal();  // \p{XDigit}
assertThat(string).isPrintable();    // \p{Print}
assertThat(string).isVisible();      // \p{Graph}

Also, the existing containsOnlyDigits() should be deprecated in favor of isDigit().

node.title: Assert return value of callable throwing exception
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

It would be nice if the assertThatCode().doesNotThrowException() API would be able execute functions that return a value and then return that value for further inspection.
This would make it easy to provide a nice description to an otherwise maybe nondescript exception that is thrown.

Example

@Test 
public void intendedApi() {
  int x = assertThatCode(this::doStuff)
    .describedAs("doing things")
    .doesNotThrowAnyException();
  assertThat(x).isEqualTo(3);
}

@Test
public void currentSolution1() {
  int x;
  try {
    x = doStuff();
  } catch (Exception e) {
    fail("doing things");
    return; // never reached; needed because fail() is not recognized by the java compiler as method exit
  }
  assertThat(x).isEqualTo(3);
}

@Test
public void currentSolution2() {
  AtomicReference<Integer> x = new AtomicReference<>();
  assertThatCode(() -> x.set(doStuff()))
    .describedAs("doing things")
    .doesNotThrowAnyException();
  assertThat(x.get()).isEqualTo(3);
}

// utility for demonstration purposes
public int doStuff() throws Exception {
  if (new Random().nextBoolean()) {
    throw new Exception();
  }
  return 3;
}

pullRequest.title: Fix containsExactly that does not work properly with maps not using e

node.title: `containsExactly` does not work properly with maps not using equals to compare keys
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

This test should pass but fails.

  @Test
  void should_pass_if_case_insensitive_actual_contains_given_entries_in_rder() {
    // GIVEN
    actual = new CaseInsensitiveMap<>();
    actual.put( "Color", "green" );
    actual.put( "NAME", "Yoda" );

    // THEN
    maps.assertContainsExactly(someInfo(), actual, entry("COLOR", "green"), entry("Name", "Yoda"));
  }

The underlying issue is when containsExactly verifies that the entries are in the same order, it ends up comparing "Color" against "COLOR" with equals instead of the actual map key comparison strategy (case insensitive string in the example).

It's not yet clear if there is a way to address this issue, if not we would have to mention the limitation in the javadoc.

node.title: `assertThat(comparable)` returns `ObjectAssert` instead of `AbstractComparableAssert`
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Given a Comparable<T> variable, it's currently not possible to use assertions from ComparableAssert unless T is Object.

Also, if the type implementing Comparable targets a parent type that is not Object, assertThat always returns ObjectAssert for both strongly-typed and Comparable<T> variables.

Example: JDK type not comparing with Object

Comparable<String> comparable = "value";

assertThat(comparable)            // ObjectAssert<Comparable<String>>
  .isEqualByComparingTo("value"); // does not compile

Example: Custom type comparing with self

class ComparingWithSelf implements Comparable<ComparingWithSelf> {
  @Override
  public int compareTo(ComparingWithSelf other) {
    return 0;
  }
}

Comparable<ComparingWithSelf> comparable = new ComparingWithSelf();

assertThat(comparable)                            // ObjectAssert<Comparable<ComparingWithSelf>>
  .isEqualByComparingTo(new ComparingWithSelf()); // does not compile

ComparingWithSelf comparingWithSelf = new ComparingWithSelf();

assertThat(comparingWithSelf)                     // AbstractComparableAssert<?, ComparingWithSelf>
  .isEqualByComparingTo(new ComparingWithSelf()); // compiles

Example: Custom type comparing with parent

class Parent {}

class ComparingWithParent extends Parent implements Comparable<Parent> {
  @Override
  public int compareTo(Parent other) {
    return 0;
  }
}

Comparable<Parent> comparable = new ComparingWithParent();

assertThat(comparable)                              // ObjectAssert<Comparable<Parent>>
  .isEqualByComparingTo(new ComparingWithParent()); // does not compile

ComparingWithParent comparingWithParent = new ComparingWithParent();

assertThat(comparingWithParent)                     // ObjectAssert<ComparingWithParent>
  .isEqualByComparingTo(new ComparingWithParent()); // does not compile

Example: Custom type comparing with Object

class ComparingWithObject implements Comparable<Object> {
  @Override
  public int compareTo(Object other) {
    return 0;
  }
}

Comparable<Object> comparable = new ComparingWithObject();

assertThat(comparable)                              // AbstractComparableAssert<?, Comparable<Object>
  .isEqualByComparingTo(new ComparingWithObject()); // compiles

ComparingWithObject comparingWithObject = new ComparingWithObject();

assertThat(comparingWithObject)                     // AbstractComparableAssert<?, ComparingWithObject>
  .isEqualByComparingTo(new ComparingWithObject()); // compiles

Workaround: Raw type

Comparable comparable = "value";  // "rawtypes" warning

assertThat(comparable)            // AbstractComparableAssert<?, Comparable> with "unchecked" warning
  .isEqualByComparingTo("value"); // compiles with "unchecked" warning

Workaround: asInstanceOf

This works only with non-null instances due to the null-check performed in asInstanceOf.

Comparable<String> comparable = "value";

assertThat(comparable)                    // ObjectAssert<Comparable<String>>
  .asInstanceOf(comparable(String.class)) // AbstractComparableAssert<?, String>
  .isEqualByComparingTo("value");         // compiles

Current status

assertThat use case Comparable<T> variable Strongly-typed variable
JDK type not comparing with Object ObjectAssert N/A (dedicated assertions)
Custom type comparing with self ObjectAssert AbstractComparableAssert
Custom type comparing with parent ObjectAssert ObjectAssert
Custom type comparing with Object AbstractComparableAssert AbstractComparableAssert

node.title: Regression in `AbstractMapAssert#containsOnlyKeys` with Spring's `MultiValueMapAdapter`
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

We saw this when updating from AssertJ 3.19.0 to 3.20.0. It appears that AbstractMapAssert#containsOnlyKeys is mutating the map that we're asserting on, which leads to test failures in our case. This is happening on an instance of org.springframework.util.MultiValueMapAdapter

Example

var underlyingMap = new HashMap<String, List<String>>();
underlyingMap.put("Hello", List.of("World"));

var multiValueMap = CollectionUtils.toMultiValueMap(underlyingMap);
// This assertion passes
assertThat(multiValueMap).containsOnlyKeys("Hello");
// This assertion fails, as `multiValueMap` and `underlyingMap` are now empty
assertThat(multiValueMap).containsOnlyKeys("Hello");

The issue seems to have been introduced in #2167, and is caused by this use of Map#remove on a "clone" of the Map being asserted on. In our case that Map is a Spring MultiValueMapAdapter, which delegates operations to the underlying Map that it was constructed from. The remove call on the clone delegates to multiValueMap#remove which in turn delegates to underlyingMap#remove.

pullRequest.title: urlassert

node.title: Add `isReachable` / `isUnreachable` for URL assertions
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Inspired by junit-pioneer/junit-pioneer#468, isReachable / isUnreachable assertions could be added to AbstractUrlAssert.

One of the most valuable use cases could be when the assertion is used as an assumption, allowing to skip a test if a remote dependency is not available.

The assertion name could be generic enough (i.e., not strictly bound to HTTP) and internally we could have different behaviors based on the protocol.

At first, the target should be only HTTP URLs.

This gist might inspire the assertion implementation.

Example

assertThat(new URL("http://google.com")).isReachable();
assertThat(new URL("http://invalid")).isUnreachable();

Points to discuss

  • Naming: isReachable good enough, especially if we want to have it generic? What about isAccessible or exists?
  • Testing: MockServer? Something else?
  • Should we support HTTPS? We might need to disable certificate chain and hostname validation
  • Method: GET vs HEAD
  • What to do with redirects

pullRequest.title: reference Fixes #1355

node.title: Describe actual Throwables when ThrowableAssert fails
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

When some Throwable-related assertion fails the actual Throwable that failed the check is not described beyond what actually caused assertion failure (e.g. message mismatch). In non trivial code when unexpected Exceptions are thrown this makes debugging inconvenient.

Dumping more comprehensive (class, message, stack, perhaps even recursive info about causes) info about the actual Throwable could ease assertion failure investigation.

Relevant message factories (e.g. ShouldHaveMessage) already have access to actual Throwable.

It may be tempting to use util.Throwables.ERROR_DESCRIPTION_EXTRACTOR to describe throwables, but more powerful mechanism would be appreciated.
Providing a precise information in case of assertion failure doesn't seem to be overkill (unlike as in #864)

Error message to improve

  • ShouldHaveCause
  • ShouldHaveCauseExactlyInstance
  • ShouldHaveCauseInstance
  • ShouldHaveCauseReference - @weiyilei
  • ShouldHaveNoCause
  • ShouldHaveNoSuppressedExceptions
  • ShouldHaveRootCauseExactlyInstance
  • ShouldHaveRootCauseInstance
  • ShouldHaveSuppressedException
  • ShouldNotContainCharSequence

node.title: Float/Double precision bugs about assertion within the certain range
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Considering the following 2 cases, they both try to assert double values is equal to expected in the certain range. But these two assertions have different behaviours. It should be a serious bug, and hope the team can look at it.

Example

assertThat(0.125f).isEqualTo(0.5f, within(0.375f)); // pass!
assertThat(1.1f).isEqualTo(1.0f, within(0.1f)); // fail!

For the second assertion, the running result is:

java.lang.AssertionError: 
Expecting actual:
  1.1f
to be close to:
  1.0f
by less than 0.1f but difference was 0.100000024f.

node.title: Add more assertion on ClassAssert
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

Apologies, If I'm wrong.

It's nice that the ClassAssert already has an assertion for Class#isAssignableFrom.
An assertion of opposite flow may be more intuitive, I believe.
Say, we have the following class or any other class being expected to implement the MyInterface interface.

class MyClass
        extends HisClass // which extends HerClass
        implements MyInterface {
}
HerClass
    HisClass
        MyClass

We can,

// Asserts that MyInterface.class is assignable from MyClass.class, based on Class#isAssignableFrom
assertThat(MyInterface.class)
        .isAssignableFrom(MyClass.class);
// Asserts that MyClass.class has HisClass.class as direct superclass.
assertThat(MyClass.class)
        .hasSuperclass(HisClass.class);

But following idiom(s) will be more intuitive.

// Asserts that MyClass implements MyInterface
assertThat(MyClass.class)
        .implements(MyInterface.class)
        .isAssignableTo(MyInterface.class);
// Or
assertThat(MyClass.class)
        .implements(MyInterface.class)
        .isSubclassOf(HisClass.class) // is direct subclass; opposite of hasSuperclass(superClass)
        .isDescendentOf(HisClass.class)
        .isDescendentOf(HerClass.class) // is direct or transitively
;
assertThat(HisClass.class)
        .isAscendentOf(MyClass.class)
        .isSubclassOf(HerClass.class)
        .isDescendentOf(HerClass.class);
  • isAssignableTo(classOrInterface)
  • implements(interfaceClass)
  • isSubclassOf(superClass) - is direct subclass of
  • is(Descendant|Descendent)Of(ascendentClass) - is direct or transitive descendent of
  • is(Ancestor|Ascendent)Of(descendentClass) - is direct or transitive ascendent of

pullRequest.title: Improved runtime of containsExactly

node.title: Improve the performance of `containsExactly` from quadratic to linear complexity
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

The performance of the containsExactly function of Iterables is currently quadratic, while it could be linear. It seems to be because of the IterableDiff class it uses, which checks the extra and missing elements with an algorithm suitable for checking the elements in any order. However, this is not necessary, since they have to be present in the exact order and so a more efficient linear solution could look something like this:

boolean compare(expected, actual) {
    if (expected.size() != actual.size()) return false;
    for (int i = 0; i < expected.size(); i++) {
       if (expected.get(i) != actual.get(i)) return false;
    }
    return true;
}

We ran a scalability analysis on various assertions, which you can find here if you are interested.

pullRequest.title: Only compare comparingOnlyFields if it is set (#2610)

node.title: Comparing only fields of different classes can pass with different values of the compared fields
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

When comparing different classes and specifying comparingOnlyFields the assertion could pass even if the compared values are different if one of the classes has more fields than the other.

I tested using the code in the main branch (ee52be2).

Example

public class ComparingOnlyTest {
  static class A1 {
    public final int a, b;
    public A1(int a, int b) {
      this.a = a;
      this.b = b;
    }
  }
  static class A2 {
    public final int a;
    public A2(int a) {
      this.a = a;
    }
  }

  @Test
  public void testComparingOnly() {
    A1 a1 = new A1(1, 2);
    A2 a2 = new A2(2);

    // This passes. Switching the places of a1 and a2 causes the assertion to fail as expected
    Assertions.assertThat(a1).usingRecursiveComparison().comparingOnlyFields("a").isEqualTo(a2);
  }
}

pullRequest.title: Overload returns() and add returnsValue() & returnsEmpty()

node.title: Extending AbstractAssert.returns
node.bodyHTML:
New variants of the returns assertions

The returns assertion could be even more useful if there would be variations for Optionals. I suggest returnsValue(expected, function) as counterpart to the hasValue assertion to check Optional return values.

It would also be nice to have a description without writing .as("..."). This also holds true for the normal returns assertion and is already done for the matches assertion.

So in total I would suggest to add the following assertion functions:

  • returns(expected, function, description)
  • returnsValue(expected, function, description)
  • returnsEmpty(function, description)

Example

class ObjectUnderTest {
  private Optional<String> optString;
  
  ObjectUnderTest(Optional<String> o) {
    optString = o;
  }

  Optional<String> getOptString() {
    return optString;
  }
}

@Test
void should_pass_optional_returns() {
  // GIVEN
  ObjectUnderTest out = new ObjectUnderTest(Optional.of("test string");
  // THEN
  assertThat(out).returnsValue("test string", ObjectUnderTest::getOptString);
}

pullRequest.title: Add `asBoolean|Byte|Short|Int|Long|Float|Double` to `String` assertions

node.title: Add (Abstract)StringAssert#as(Boolean|Byte|Short|Integer|Long|Float|Double)
node.bodyHTML:
Summary

This is a refined feature request derived from #2509.
Per @scordio's commented, it might be reasonable to add following signatures.

AbstractStringAssert#asBoolean() returns BooleanAssert

AbstractStringAssert#asByte() returns ByteAssert
AbstractStringAssert#asByte(int radix) returns ByteAssert

AbstractStringAssert#asShort() returns ShortAssert
AbstractStringAssert#asShort(int radix) returns ShortAssert

AbstractStringAssert#asInteger() returns IntegerAssert
AbstractStringAssert#asInteger(int radix) returns IntegerAssert

AbstractStringAssert#asLong() returns LongAssert
AbstractStringAssert#asLong(int radix) returns LongAssert

AbstractStringAssert#asFloat() returns FloatAssert

AbstractStringAssert#asDouble() returns DoubleAssert

NumberFormatException throwable from those parse...(String) methods, except the Boolean#parseBoolean, should be regarded as failing assertions.

Example

assertThat("yes")
//        .isNotNull() // implicit
        .asBoolean()
        .isTrue(); // fails
assertThat("32")
        .asInteger()
        .isEqualTo(32); // succeeds
assertThat(".0d")
        .asDouble()
        .isZero();

@Retention(RetentionPolicy.RUNTIME)

pullRequest.title: [ISSUE 2629] Improve readability of containsExactly

node.title: Display Improve readability of containsExactly when the order of elements does not match
node.bodyHTML:
Feature summary

assertThat(Arrays.asList(1, 2, 3, 4)).containsExactly(1, 3, 2, 4);

yields the following error message:

java.lang.AssertionError: 
Actual and expected have the same elements but not in the same order, at index 1 actual element was:
  2
whereas expected element was:
  3

Note that 1 and 4 are not displayed in the error message.

I suggest that AssertJ should print the full expected and actual set of elements in case the order does not match.

For instance, when the value does not match, then AssertJ does print all the elements:

assertThat(Arrays.asList(1, 2, 3, 4)).containsExactly(1, 2, 4, 4);
java.lang.AssertionError: 
Expecting actual:
  [1, 2, 3, 4]
to contain exactly (and in same order):
  [1, 2, 4, 4]
but some elements were not found:
  [4]
and others were not expected:
  [3]

Example

The following methods seems to be affected:

org.assertj.core.api.AbstractIterableAssert#containsExactly(ELEMENT... values)
org.assertj.core.api.AbstractIterableAssert#containsExactlyElementsOf(Iterable<? extends ELEMENT> iterable)

node.title: `returns` and `doesNotReturn` should honor custom type comparators
node.bodyHTML:
Feature summary

Currently, comparators set via usingComparatorForType are ignored by returns and doesNotReturn assertions.

We could enhance the implementation so that custom comparators are also used with these two methods.

Source: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/73121345/

Example

@Test
void test() {
    assertThat(new BigDecimal("10.00"))
        .usingComparatorForType(BigDecimalComparator.BIG_DECIMAL_COMPARATOR, BigDecimal.class)
        .returns(BigDecimal.TEN, BigDecimal::abs); // currently fails
}

node.title: assertContainsIgnoringCase fails to compare i and I in tr_TR locale
node.bodyHTML:
See org.assertj.core.internal.Strings#assertContainsIgnoringCase

https://github.com/assertj/assertj-core/blob/9051a958e6ab0a750bb243060aef57001ab97e6e/src/main/java/org/assertj/core/internal/Strings.java#L528-L531

I would suggest adding https://github.com/policeman-tools/forbidden-apis verification to just ban toLowerCase(), toUpperCase() and other unsafe methods: #2664

pullRequest.title: Add AbstractClassAssert#isPrimitive() and AbstractClassAssert#isNotPrimitive()

node.title: Add AbstractClassAssert#is(Not)Primitive()
node.bodyHTML:
Feature summary

The AbstractClassAssert lacks with is(Not)Primitive().

Example

assertThat(int.class).isPrimitive();
assertThat(String.class).isNotPrimitive();

There is already workarounds for the case, I know.

assertThat(c.isPrimitive()).isTrue();

I just found a case regarding the .as(...).

for (Field file : findSomeSpecificFields()) {
    assertThat(field.getType().isPrimitive())
        .as("@NullableBySpecification on primitive field: %s", field)
        .isFalse();
}

which may be more fluent,

for (Field file : findSomeSpecificFields()) {
    assertThat(field.getType())
        .as("%s annotated with @NullableBySpecification, field)
        .isNotPrimitive();
    //  '...Class#field annotated with @NullableBySpecification should not be primitive.
}
